2014, and the archive collection opening at the London Metropolitan Archives in May 2014, here: Rainbow Jews LGBT History Project
Rainbow Jews has numerous supporters and followers in and outside Britain, and even Stephen Fry got behind the landmark #rjexhibition launch via Twitter:


More clips, oral histories and photos can be found here, click via our Indigogo campaign Gallery (top of left tab), or via our Website or RJ You Tube Channel.


Why We Need YouRainbow
Jews is a volunteer-led initiative, hosted by the charity Liberal Judaism, and was so far supported generously by the Lottery
Heritage Fund; the 2-year one-off grant has now finished. With the current cuts in public funding we need further aid from other sources to continue our work. We believe in your community spirit - and in Rainbow Jews, and we want to keep making a difference. Now we ask you, our friends and supporters, to help us make this legacy go on. 
How Will The Money Be Spent?If we raise £5000, we will be able to cover some core costs during our UK mini tour until November 2014. Your donation will help us to: 
- cover staff costs for a part-time project manager, who will coordinate the volunteers, and continue to promote our key activities, such as:
- getting this
wonderful exhibition around the country so that we can further share these amazing
stories and experiences, (We have already confirmed Leicester, Birmingham and Liverpool/Homotopia as from 31 August 2014; with more possibilities e.g. Belfast).
- create over 5 events such as launch receptions, film screenings and talks while touring.
- disseminate our education resources, and co-facilitate sessions at school, youth groups etc.
- recording and processing of over 10 new oral histories, especially of Jewish LGBT pioneers in remoter UK regions.
- collecting more memorabilia and fostering our archive collection at LMA.
If we raise less than £5000, we will do our best to achieve as many of our goals as possible. So far we have raised the costs for the Rainbow Jews exhibition in Leicester thanks to generous donors of Leicester’s Jewish & LGBT community
and friends.
What happens over £5000?
If we reach our goal of £5000 that will be amazing. If we can raise funds over this amount, we'll be able to do even more. The charity Liberal Judaism will ensure that the money is used sensibly after November 2014, and for years to come, to:
- cover expenses for Rainbow Jews volunteers and volunteer training.
- nurture and grow our archive collection at LMA.
- continue touring the RJ exhibition (e.g. Limmud Conference Warwick 2014, Brighton for LGBT History Month 2015)
- keep organising regular community/awareness events (e.g. Brighton launch).
- keep educating the wider community about J-LGBT issues (e.g. produce toolkit)
- sustain the Rainbow Jews Website, social media channels, and promote the initiative globally.

What You Get
There are different perks for different donation levels. You can check out the perks on the right side of this page. Not your thing? We are always happy to listen, and you can of course opt out of the rewards scheme in case you feel that saving Rainbow Jews is already enough of an incentive :).



Who's Making This? Rainbow Jews is run by the wonderful team of the charity Liberal Judaism, and has been going on for almost two years because of the tireless efforts of one person, manager and founder Surat, and a growing 
community of dedicated volunteers and supporters. Find out about our team - click here Why is Rainbow Jews so important? 


"I am honoured to support Rainbow Jews and to 
celebrate the huge positive contribution that Jewish people make to the 
LGBT community and to our wider society. Jewish and LGBT people share 
many parallels of oppression and of triumph over adversity. As victims 
of prejudice, it is important for us to stand together united against 
all hate."  (Peter Tatchell, human rights veteran) 

"Rainbow Jews provides an important source of Jewish 
history. I urge people to get involved and support this project in 
whichever way they can"
(Rabbi Danny Rich, CEO Liberal Judaism)


“Rainbow Jews doesn’t just reflect LGBT history, it reflects over 50 years of British and world Jewry, We’ve heard stories going back even further than the Holocaust, from diaspora across the continents. Identities are multifaceted, and this project shows the interconnection between faith identity and other identities. It’s about being  a cohesive comunity, working together and respecting each other. Today we can see that this has happened; we have has over 80 people donating their time, skills and energy  to Rainbow Jews.  And, I'd say  - in line with  Eurovision drag star Conchita : 'we are unstoppable!” (Surat Knan, RJ founder) 

What Else Can I Do?  


Even if you can't donate, or can only contribute a little, there's still a lot you can do: 
Help get the Rainbow Jews appeal noticed! Share this campaign everywhere you can!
Use the built-in Indiegogo share tools to spread this on your social networks.
Become a long-term supporter! The charity Liberal Judaism is able to take donations directly. Speak to us about possibilities. 


Thank you for your support.
Surat, Rainbow Jews founder and manager, and the dedicated RJ volunteer team x

A  final message from Surat, Rainbow Jews founder :'Please donate right now, so we can make sure that our history will not become our past.'





Photo above courtesy of Grant Denkinson

story:
Make Me a Midwife!

Help me to attend the ICTC Black Midwives and Healers Conference in Miami.

The world needs more midwives.  The U.S. especially needs more midwives of color. Although the United States spends the most money on maternity care than any other nation, our infant mortality rates are unacceptable for a developed nation.  African American Infants are particulary at risk by being 2-3 times more likely to die before their first birthday, than infants of other races. You can help improve the health of mothers and babies in Los Angeles and beyond by supporting my journey to becoming a Certified Professional Midwife.

You may ask what is a midwife?  A midwife is a professional healthcare provider who provides women's health care focusing particularly on common primary care issues, family planning and gynecologic needs of women, pregnancy, childbirth, the postpartum period and the care of the newborn.  Midwives believe that birth is a normal, natural, healthy process.  Midwifery care emphasis is on increased personalized prenatal care and low intervention birth.

My name is Camille Brown. I am a mother, Doula, Student Midwife, and Early Intervention Social Worker.  I discovered my passion for being a Doula after having a natural hospital birth with my first child.  I realized after the birth of my son how powerful and transformative pregnancy and birth can be.  I also realized how little informational, emotional and psychological support is typically available to women.  A little over a year ago I realized that I need to increase my skills and capacity to serve mothers and babies by becoming Certified Professional Midwife.  I am passionate about helping to improve the health outcomes of mothers and babies through informed, compassionate midwifery care.

In my work as a Social Worker for premature babies and children with disabilities I have seen first hand how being born too small, and too soon can affect a child his whole life. This can often lead to life long disabilities. I truly believe that many premature births can be prevented with holisitic, culturally competent midwifery care.  Midwifery is a proven safe and cost effective method of improving the birth outcomes for mothers and babies.

Help make me a Midwife by sending me to the ICTC Black Midwives and Healers Conference.

          Your funds will go directly to sending me to the ICTC Black Midwives and Healers Conference in Miami, Florida.  The dates of the conference are October 19-22, 2012.

Funding needed:

  • round trip plane ticket from LA to Miami $400.00
  • Conference Fee $405.00
  • Shared room in hotel 100.00

Information about the conference can be found at www.ictcmidwives.org

 

Supporting my attendance at ICTC Black Midwives Conference will have a real impact on allowing me to help my community through providing education, empowerment and compassionate care to childbearing families.

Check out some of the statistics for African American mothers in Los Angeles. 

"In other words, the infant mortality rate for African
Americans was more than two times the rate for LAC overall. African Americans comprised 7.6% of all births in LAC in 2006, and 18.2% (134 cases) of all infant deaths within the same period." - Los Angeles County Department of Public Health

"As of 2007, African American moms in Los Angeles are about 40% more likely to have a preterm birth and about 70% more likely to have a low birth weight baby than other mothers". - Los Angeles County Public Health Department

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends and help make me a midwife.  A donation of any amount will help me get to the conference.

Thank You, Thank You, Thank You for your encouragement and support!

story:
My name is Maria Almanza. I am a New Yorker, who is currently pursuing her education in nursing. I was visiting Nepal this summer for an independent study and to gain more hands on clinical practice. Originally my plan was to volunteer as a nurse at the hospital, College of Medical Sciences, in Chitwan, Nepal... and come back home. 

However, it turned into something much more than what I had expected. While I was doing my rounds, I noticed there were an immense amount of patients who needed hemodialysis due to kidney failure and also patients who had a plethora of cardiac diseases, and the reason being is DIABETES. Many of these medical problems could have been prevented by early diagnosis and health education. Unfortunately, the people of Nepal can not afford regular health exams, and therefore, many are living with DIABETES AND THEY DO NOT EVEN KNOW... UNTIL IT IS TOO LATE. 

These patients do not have medical insurance in order to receive any type of health care. Patients literally have to sell their homes and all of their belongings just to get hemodialysis, treatment, which cost about 3,500 Rupees/week  ($43.00US). That does not include the cost of hospital stay; medication, lab work, food, and other needed resources. Patients need to pay for everything out of their pocket!  When I learned this, I knew I wanted to help. I set up a meeting with the Director of College of Medical Sciences, and told him about my desire to help. He informed me that chronic diseases are drastically rising in Nepal, and the government does not provide any help for the people.  

With good fortune and help from the hospital I was volunteering at, I started a local Non Profit Organization in Nepal; College of Medical Sciences Diabetic Foundation, which is correlated with Bucketts of Love – Help Save Nepal. There is a committee of doctors and nurses and well renowned community leaders, who are willing to volunteer their time and take me to the villages of Chitwan.  The goal is to provide free health care, which includes: diabetic testing, administering medication, and educating the local people about nutrition and health issues. Many people live hours away from any hospital or health post, with no access to any form of transportation.  If patients need to go to a hospital or doctor, transportation will be provided by the foundation.

College of Medical Sciences Diabetic Foundation (Bucketts of Love- Help Save Nepal) will make an IMMENSE impact on the lives of the people of Nepal and can change the future of Nepal’s healthcare system. 

 How can you help? Donate! You can contact me directly through email with any questions you may have. There is no “middle man” here. All donations will go through me. I am returning back to Nepal in February to start my work. I will be in direct contact with the patients, doctors, nurses, pharmacists and medical suppliers. Your money will be directly forwarded to the sustainability of the foundation.

 Here is a brief breakdown of where the funds will be going:

 $10.00 will provide $70.00 worth of medical supplies such as wound dressing, linens and educational material

$25.00 will provide $175.00 worth of medical equipment such as stethoscopes and blood pressure machines.

$25.00 will provide insulin for 50 patients

$50.00 will purchase an exam bed

$75.00 will purchase a hospital bed

$100.00 will provide an insulin pump for 50 patients

$500.00 will establish a pharmacy

$1,500 will establish a community lab

$3,000 will establish the construction of a local clinic

If you would like to donate supplies rather than money, that is completely POSSIBLE!

If you can not make any kind of donation at the moment, please spread the word!  

Our future goal is to build a clinic equipped with exam rooms, a pharmacy, a fitness room and a yoga/ meditation center.

 

With the help of your donations we can make a huge impact on the needy people of Nepal. Please BE AWARE AND SHARE.

story:
We are currently running the first Mission: Physics Peer-to-Peer Teaching Competition.  Students across the US are creating and submitting videos (<2 min) teaching their peers about Newton's Universal Law of Gravitation.  Generally speaking, the videos are focused on freshman in high school. 

We've created a set of sample videos to get the creative juices flowing.
Check out our show: "What the FisX" at www.wtfisx.com!

PRIZES FOR STUDENTS ARE:

1st: $1000
2nd: $500
3rd: $150
4th: $150
5th: $100


Risks and challenges

Of the $2500 being raised, $2000 is going directly to prize money for students. As we already have more than five teams involved, there will automatically be at least five winners - the money will get to its target. ---- NO RISK

The rewards being given away are fairly easy to produce and distribute.  Standard issues could arise in printing or shipping which could delay the products --- SMALL RISK

Advertising space on the first 5 seconds of the 'Cat Box' segment is very easy to implement. Please contact us first via our website to ensure your business is aligned with our goals. --- LOW RISK

The 'Cat Box' seats being given away for Episode II will assist in funding the production of Episode II. This ensures the project moves forward. --- LOW RISK

The quality of the videos submitted by students could be less than amazing --- NO RISK

story:
Short Summary

A need has been expressed by the community to record and post the BAS Board Meetings online, but it can't happen without your support. My name is George Fox. I was contracted to record a few meetings in 2014 and the response was positive. Without hiring a professional there will likely be no consistent video record of these meetings made available in 2015.
 
I'm proposing that anyone interested in documenting or keeping current on the meetings' happenings -- please give what you can. Obviously, if you can attend the meetings, that is best. This is not intended to be a replacement for attending a meeting. Public comment is one of the most powerful tools we have to shape the policy our board implements.

I'm an MSU grad, professional videographer and an area resident. My son will be entering Brighton Area Schools in fall of 2015 so I have a vested interest in transparent and healthy school board meetings.

What We Need & What You Get

  • $90 is fair to record each 1 hour 30 minute meeting, maximize the recorded picture and sound and make it available to the world. I spend a total of 3-4 hours recording and posting each meeting. I've made a package of the 22 meetings at a 25% discount. I've added back in the estimated 7% fees that Indiegogo charges, hence the $1,589 figure.
  • The videos will be uploaded on the following day by noon barring technical glitches. You can see a samples of the audio and video quality from previous meetings on the Brighton Area Schools Board Meeting Video YouTube channel.
If we don't reach the goal by Dec 27th at 11:59 p.m. -- all of the money will be refunded.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Direct anyone who might be able to help fund the project to this page. igg.me/at/bas-board-meetings-2015

story:
10th May 2015: Udabno Rural Festival!

Udabno is a remote village in South-Eastern Georgia, just 15km from the borders with Azerbaijan. Its name literally means "desert" and that is how it looks - the area with almost no connection to the bigger settlement (the closest town is about 40 minutes of driving on a really bad road), inhabited by the eco-migrants who were resettled here in early 80s by the Soviet government. The biggest property of the locals are their cows and sheeps and their unique, specific culture and folklore that they strive to preserve. People, and especially local youngsters have very limited opportunities to develop themselves, to learn something beyond their school classes, share their skills and learn new ones, discover different lifestyles...

Our aim is to create a positive example of an event organized in such rural area, through which some of the needs of the community will be addressed. Our cultural and educational festival will introduce various workshops and discussions conducted by the involved organizations, young volunteers, artists, representatives of Georgian business, international guests and by the local youngsters. 

We want to bring attention of wide public to the cultural specifics of the community, but also to their problems and issues.

What are our main objectives?

1) We are organizing an open-air cultural and educational festival in the rural area that will be free of charge for all the visitors. 

2) We will offer various workshops based on non-formal education principles boosting intercultural knowledge, artistic and media expression, capability to be part of civic society and public discussion, entrepreneurial skills and other competencies to the local inhabitants and all the visitors of the event. 

3) By this festival we want to bring attention of the wide public to the traditions and characteristics of Udabno by inviting guests from different parts of Georgia. 

4) We will promote economic potential of Udabno village and support the networking and cooperation between the local production and business companies represented in the region. 

5) And finally, through this event we want to initiate close cooperation of the organizations from civic and non-governmental sector and the local community.

There will be workshops on film making, entrepreneurial games, handcrafts, folklore dances, creative recycling, language learning workshop, intercultural workshop, film screening and others!


Who are we?

We are a consortium of two non-governmental organizations from Georgia and their partners from Europe. 

Youth Association DRONI is a youth association working for and with young people since 2003. It is one of the biggest and most experienced organizations in Georgia in the youth field, implementing numerous local and international projects every year. The organization covers various topics that are actual for young people in Georgia, such as: Human rights education, environmental protection, media, non-formal education, civil activism, art and culture, peace building, entrepreneurship, volunteering etc. The target groups of the organization are mainly young people with fewer opportunities, youngsters from rural areas, IDPs and youth from SOS village. (http://droni-youth.org/)

Go Group Media was established in 2009 by a group of professional journalists and editors, and it works mainly in Georgia and the South Caucasus region. One of the key-targets is creation of greater opportunities for ordinary members of society, including members of minority groups, to respond to new realities and play a more active role in decision-making in the region and beyond. Among the main activities of the organization are: 1) Eyewitness Studio, 2) Journalistic expeditions to the misreported or underreported regions offering a way to contribute to the solution of a complicated problem of society dissociation, 3) Caucasus Authors Course, 4) Production of feature length documentaries. (http://www.gogroupmedia.net/)


What We Need 

All our work on the festival is voluntary. The money from this crowdfunding will be used: 

  • to offer free transportation to the visitors of the festival from Tbilisi. There is no regular connection to Udabno. 
  • to buy used wooden pallets, paints and tools. With these materials we will create benches and little stages for our festival, which will later on stay in the village - You may not believe that but there is not a single bench in the public areas of the village.
  • to rent a sound equipment for the folklore band and young Georgian musicians we want to invite for the event. 
  • to buy the materials for the workshops, such as handcrafting, products for international cooking workshop 
  • to organize small refreshment and pay the local ladies for cooking their delicious meals they will offer to the visitors.

How to help us?

Of course we will appreciate your contribution of any amount! 
If you are around in the region we will be also happy to see you on 10th May in Udabno, we will make a special Georgian toast for you! You can also come and help us with the preparations: making the benches, preparing the snacks, preparing the whole thing!

The organization covers various topics that are actual for young people in Georgia, such as: Human rights education, environmental protection, media, non-formal education, civil activism, art and culture, peace building, entrepreneurship, volunteering etc. The target groups of the organization are mainly young people with fewer opportunities, youngsters from rural areas, IDPs and youth from SOS village. (http://droni-youth.org/)

Go Group Media was established in 2009 by a group of professional journalists and editors, and it works mainly in Georgia and the South Caucasus region. One of the key-targets is creation of greater opportunities for ordinary members of society, including members of minority groups, to respond to new realities and play a more active role in decision-making in the region and beyond. Among the main activities of the organization are: 1) Eyewitness Studio, 2) Journalistic expeditions to the misreported or underreported regions offering a way to contribute to the solution of a complicated problem of society dissociation, 3) Caucasus Authors Course, 4) Production of feature length documentaries. (http://www.gogroupmedia.net/)

What We Need 
 All our work on the festival is voluntary. The money from this crowdfunding will be used: 


to offer free transportation to the visitors of the festival from Tbilisi. There is no regular connection to Udabno. 

to buy used wooden pallets, paints and tools. With these materials we will create benches and little stages for our festival, which will later on stay in the village - You may not believe that but there is not a single bench in the public areas of the village.
to rent a sound equipment for the folklore band and young Georgian musicians we want to invite for the event. 
to buy the materials for the workshops, such as handcrafting, products for international cooking workshop 
to organize small refreshment and pay the local ladies for cooking their delicious meals they will offer to the visitors.

    How to help us?
Of course we will appreciate your contribution of any amount! 
If you are around in the region we will be also happy to see you on 10th May in Udabno, we will make a special Georgian toast for you! You can also come and help us with the preparations: making the benches, preparing the snacks, preparing the whole thing!

story:
OUR Mission: We change lives by making good teachers great. 

The GoodBrain Project builds great schools by recruiting, supporting, and developing top teaching and leadership talent in NYC & nationwide.

Our objective is to provide K-12 students with equal access to post-secondary opportunities worthy of their potential.

 

What We Are: Our P.U.R.P.O.S.E.

A thinking and solution partner for Victory Collegiate High School, where students and teachers are collaborating to broaden 

Perspective in order to increase  

Understanding of the world, through a

Rigorous practice of

Problem Solving. We facilitate

Open communication of challenges and opportunties to build a shared

Social Consciousness thereby exceeding the world's

Expectations of traditionally underestimated populations of students and teachers. 

 

Why Victory Collegiate

Victory Collegiate is a place where the business of teaching and learning is a way of life. It's a safe and practical laboratory founded by a visionary Principal and Assistant Principal in a nearly forgotten building in Brooklyn's Canarsie, where so many people still believe our kids will never make it. It is not a place to be perfect, but it affords a chance to create a "more perfect union." It's a public school space where some of the most talented students and the finest teacher-leaders in NYC are building a community that celebrates the individual as a shaper of our collective humanity. It's the promise of a P.U.R.P.O.S.E that allows students and teachers to professionally practice our shared values of "life, liberty & the pursuit of happiness." 

 

What We Need:

Your investment ($5 - ? ) in these Transformational Leaders in Education

 

What You Receive NOW!

A school that is HOME for teachers, students & their families

A successful experiment in providing equal education & access to opportunity or power historically reserved for a small minority of Americans

Respect for Resources: Reconfigured, Redefined, and Extended Teaching & Learning Time 

Valued, Empowered & Developed Teacher Talent Teams who  love and lead their students to personal Victory

 

What you Receive Later!

Abundant joy and the material riches of a nation where no human is left behind by historical underestimations or fear-driven assumptions. 

Permission to Grow Your Own Greatness by investing in the Growth of Others' Greatness

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get involved in Public Schooling.

Got Know How? Petition your School Board to volunteer to teach a class or lead a trip of students (teachers & parents if kids scare you). All it takes is a thorough background check, a quick set of fingerprints, and some strong personal references to be a member of your local school community.

Got Time? If hands on service is not your thing, help The Good Brain Project build a mobile professional development platform that actually inspires students, teachers, and parents to take risks, teach up, and speak out about what they need to Grow their Greatness.

Got A Computer? Form an on-line parent or local awareness group to support parents in asking their kids and answering the hard questions about the risks and rewards of life in 2013.

Got a Community? Talk to kids and find out what they need to address their concerns. Ask your church, temple, mosque, ashram, yoga studio or a local restauraunt to host  a totally uncensored discussion about sex, drugs, and alcohol among teenagers in your community. 

Got Gumption? Ask this question of your policy makers: why do we spend an average of $88,000 to imprison a young mind and only $8,800 to shape one?

Got Dough? For $3,200 buy 2 days or 24 hours of direct service to continue to fertilize our affiliate school Victory Collegiate. For $100,000, give a full year of all day, every day service of a GoodBrain Project trained Coach. See what happens when Greatness Grows.

story:
Dear Friends,

 

I am not going through this campaign anymore, I ask you to not donate anymore, as I am unable to attend the Singularity University.

 

 

Hello friends and thank you very much for stopping on my page!

I love medicine and all the incredible changes it can bring to so many people around the world. I can honestly say this is the only dream I have - to use medicine and technology to improve the lives of as many people as I can.

After attending the Social Entrepreneurship conference (which changed by life, no exaggeration) I met the biggest social entrepreneurs in Brazil, VCs and change-makers. I had my eyes shining all weekend to social innovation and being totally inspired. I am now fully motivated to make some amazing change happen.

Where I live medicine is about looking after one patient at a time - what I want to do is create medical solutions that will impact millions of people at a time.

Singularity University was setup by NASA, Google... and I was accepted! I know going there can make this happen for me, but I need $10,000 by Tuesday.

It no's exaggeration to say you have the power to change my life for the better and I sincerely hope you will be able to help me.

Your friend for life,

Tymo

story:
Short Summary

Two things I've always loved: God and story-telling. This past summer, I saved up money and threw myself into an adventure of a life-time. I circumnavigated the globe and made my way here to YWAM Kona in order to staff and be a part of the Voice for the Voiceless DTS, a discipleship training program with a focus in social injustice advocacy through the usage of media. 

In December 2014, I'll have the opportunity and privilege of leading a ministry team to Thailand/Myanmar in order to work with Burmese refugees, and other various persecuted ethnic groups. Our goals are simple: love the unloved, heal the broken, befriend the friendless, comfort orphans & widows, and give a voice to the voiceless. 

What Is Needed?

$3000 will go towards my air-fare and accommodations for the 3-month trip in South East Asia. It will also go towards equipment and gear that'll be a long-term investment towards my dreams and aspirations (mic, tripod, camera gear, backpack, etc.).

Anything helps. and anything is a blessing. I've never trusted God in the area of finances in my life because I've always confided in my parents. But it hasn't been easy for the #YoonClan, and I've never felt so vulnerable, broken, and in need of a miracle in my life. 

Even if you're unable to sow into me financially, would you please give me a message or a call and sow into me relationally through encouragement and prayer?

Risks & Challenges

We have absolutely no idea what type of favor we'll have with the government and the people in charge. Myanmar has had a history of corruption, violence, genocide, and danger-- it's going to be awesome.

Have you heard of the Rohingya people? They're one of the most persecuted people group in the world. We have an opportunity to hear, tell, and share the stories of persecuted minorities groups that nobody else is covering, and not many people have heard. 

Am I risking the safety of my team and myself by being public about this here? Nonsense, we'll apply for our visa's to Myanmar once we get to Thailand :)

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • If you have contacts in Thailand, Burma, or Cambodia-- Holla!
    • Send me a message or a call, encouragement! 
    • Subscribe to my newsletter! http://eepurl.com/5AA9n
    • Follow my blog! http://www.iamyohanyoon.com
    • Pray!

    And that's all there is to it. If you'd like to know me, please don't hesitate to contact me! Love you all!

story:
A Quick Summary

     My name is Samantha Strawn. I am 18 years old and I just graduated high school. In the fall I will be attending Capernwray Bible School in Lancashire, England. Throughout the year i will be diving deep into the bible and learning more about our savior, Jesus Christ. I am beyond excited to study abroad and experience a whole new chapter in my life. The only hurdle I still have is my tuition. 

     Because it is an international bible school, i do not qualify for financial aid. My father was out of work for most of last year and can not contribute that much. And the school does not offer any sort of financial assistance. That is where I would like your help.

What I Need

     Tuition for the whole year (including housing, meals, and books) is roughly around 12,000 USD.  The Majority of the tuition payment is due by the start of the term, which is September 27th, 2014. That is where the funds are going. Even if I do not reach my goal, I would still put anything I raise towards that. 

Why? 

     I am going for the Lord. That is why going is so important to me. The things I am going to learn, not just about God, but about myself and life in general, are things that I will be able to carry with me the rest of my life. 

Other Ways You Can Help

     Even if you can not give anything, that is okay. Something as little as a short prayer for me will make a huge difference! Also, pass this on to friends or family, or post it on social media. 

Also, if you would like to learn more about the school itself and what its all about go to http://www.capernwray.org.uk/BibleSchool.php

Thank you and God bless!

Jeremiah 29:11 ~ For I know the plans I have for you,” declares the Lord, “plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future."

story:
Children don't spend much time outdoors anymore, and research demonstrates that missed outdoor time  negatively affects children's physical and mental health.  At the Y, we aim to give children at least a full 60 minutes of outdoor play daily, and you can help by building our outdoor classroom!

Our not-for-profit early learning center, the Center for Children and Families, located in Bloomington, Indiana,  is licensed to educate and care for 112 young children daily while their parents or caregivers work.

Our YMCA has been in business for more than 30 years, but our early learning center opened only a year ago.  When our capital funds were used up, we still hadn't finished our outdoor classroom-- that's where you come in!

Funders will help us purchase natural outdoor building blocks  for children, including a storage shed to ensure that they last for many, many years.

Your donation will give hundreds and hundreds of children over many years access to materials that build creativity, build muscles and bring children out into nature on a daily basis. 
 
Play, and outdoor play especially, IS the work of children.  You can help them experience it more fully. 
 

What You're Funding:

Your donation will fund a preschool set of Outlast Blocks and a storage shed from Community Playthings: http://www.communityplaythings.com/products/outdoor/outlast-sets 

These specially designed blocks are meant to last for years and years in an outdoor environment while giving children the opportunity to build, and then physically interact with their structures. 

We plan to purchase the:    

  • Outlast Shed 
  • Wheelbarrow
  • Crates
  • Preschool Block Set

If we are unable to raise our full amount, we will use what we raise to purchase the pieces that we can afford outside of the full set.

 

 

The Impact:

 Rachel Carson, "A Sense of Wonder"

"Play, incorporating  animistic and magical thinking is important because it:
  -fosters the healthy,  creative and emotional growth of a child;
  -forms the best foundation  for later intellectual growth;
  -provides a way in which  children get to know the world and creates  possibilities    for different ways of  responding to it.
   -fosters empathy and  wonder."

 Valerie Andrews, A Passion for this Earth 

 "As  a child, one has that magical capacity to move among the many eras of the  earth; to see the land as an animal does; to experience the sky from the  perspective of a flower or a bee; to feel the earth quiver and breathe beneath  us; to know a hundred different smells of mud and listen un-self-consciously to  the soughing of the trees."

This article from Community Playthings spells out the myriad reasons that quality outdoor play spaces are important for young children:  http://www.communityplaythings.com/resources/articles/2010/outdoor-play 
They include:
- allowing children to be children
- fostering a positive disposition towards the outdoors
- increasing physical and mental health
- improving creativity and imagination
- exploring, risk-taking and much, much more!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate?  You can still help!  Please share our campaign with your friends and family who remember the joys of outdoor play!  Together we can make a difference for children! Use the Indiegogo share tools-- it's easy!

As always, thank you for your support!

story:
"The more that you read, the more things you will know. The more that you learn, the more places you'll go." -Dr. Seuss

Reading and building literacy skills are crucial to a child's academic development. Having access to books is at the foundation of every young learner's academic success. However, literacy rates are unequal throughout Walla Walla. Many families struggle to put food on their tables, let alone buy books for their children. These children begin school at a disadvantage, and without access to a crucial developmental resource such as books, these children increasingly fall behind in their academics. So here is an opportunity for YOU to recycle an important resource: books.

Join Whitman College Students for Education Reform (SFER) for our First Annual Book Drive. From March 31st-April 21st, we are collecting books to distribute to families and children in Walla Walla. Every book counts, and every book will find a new reader just as excited to get lost in its pages as you were in your childhood.

What We Need 

What are we looking for?
*New or used books in good condition
*Books for a wide range of readers of different ages, levels, and interests:
          -Board and cloth books for young readers (0-3 y/o)
          -Picture books
          -Beginning chapter books
          -Young adult novels

Where will Donations Go?

100% of the donations we receive from this campaign will be used to purchase books for the children of Walla Walla. We will be donating the books to Walla Walla Children's Home Society, who will then distribute the books to families in need. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are several ways you can contribute to this book drive, aside from donating on this website. Ways to help include:

  • Spreading the word about our book drive with classmates, professors, friends, community members, and family
  • Going to local bookstores and finding books to put in the donation boxes that are all around campus
  • Ordering your favorite childhood books from sites such as Amazon and sending them directly to: Stefani Paladino, 280 Boyer Ave., Walla Walla, WA 99362

We appreciate your interest and involvement in this important project. We look forward to seeing how Whitties can help improve literacy by providing more opportunities for youth to find a passion in reading. Help the children of Walla Walla have access to books so that they, too, can go places!

story:
Short Summary

I am a South African by birth and have lived in this country for 60 years. During that time I was exposed to a number of ideologies and even went through the mandatory "brain washing" we called "Citizen Service" - an excuse to send a large number of my compatriots to fight wars that were senseless and only motivated by political agendas without any substance.
During my 20's I and my wife began to realize that what we saw going on around us was not how a normal Society should operate. We began to befriend a number of "non-white" people and became close friends with some of them. Probably the tipping point for us was the day we wanted to visit our one friend's new born in the "Location" and he told us that we would be arrested if the police found us there!! To cut a long story short we got him to smuggle us in and we gave the baby her gifts. 
As strange as it may sound after 20 years of "independence" we still see a crying need for the upliftment of people who had come from a culture where no real opportunities were available and where they cannot see any changes that which would engender hope in a better future for themselves but, most critically, their children. The upsurge in violent, destructive service delivery protest is evidence of this.
I and my team have decided that we need to take action and create a new environment for our younger generation within which they can see opportunities for self improvement and upliftment. IF WE DO NOT PUT OUR CHILDREN ON A ROUTE OF HOPE AND GIVE THEM THE TOOLS WITH WHICH TO ACCOMPLISH THEIR DREAMS WE AS A NATION AND A COUNTRY HAVE NO FUTURE!! 
We reviewed what we could do and then realized that sport could be one of the greatest catalysts that, if complemented by a solid education system, could revolutionize our kid's life.
Of all the options Cricket came out as being the sports vehicle with the appropriate structures and characteristics. It is also the 2nd most popular sport in South Africa and carries no perceptible "baggage".
WHY CRICKET - it is a team game, it places high demands on concentration, it stimulates literacy and coordination, it requires discipline, the game structure lends itself naturally to being encoded in a Board Game, costs can be held down with innovative design. and finally a number of previously disadvantaged persons have become Super Sports stars playing a game at which South Africa is excelling globally!!
Our decision was to use a Cricket Board Game as the primary upliftment tool.
I spent the last  8 years working on developing a Cricket Board Game. It is now ready to be produced and distributed to the numerous Cricket Clinics and Academies that are striving to make a success in the disadvantaged areas. 
This would be directly in line with our Minister of Sport's, Mr Fikile Mbablula that "

"The smiles on the faces of the children are yet to reflect the sunshine in their hearts, because that moment is yet to come. "

THAT TIME IS NOW!!! We can do it with Sport and specifically Cricket.

The impact of the game is exceptional - $US8 will provide a youngster with a game to go out and begin playing with his circle of friends thereby getting rapid grass roots acceptance of the game.
With a solid Cricket Theory background the individual has a better than average chance of being admitted to a dedicated Academic/Cricket hybrid schools that are now in the process of being established. And if our program produces more deserving candidates the number of these schools will increase - much like the Australian model.
From the initial 5,000 players we hope to develop a  core group of 500 children who grasp the opportunity to become a Cricket player with both hands and have demonstrated the skill, dedication and aptitude,  With this number we will be able to place funding into developing a selected Schools to have the extra-mural infrastructure to specialize in intensive after school Cricket training. 

  • What We Need & What You Get

To produce a Student Traveler Cricket game costs $US8

The impact of the game is exceptional - $US8 will provide a youngster with a game to go out and begin playing with his circle of friends under the auspices of a screened Coach/Mentor thereby getting rapid grass roots acceptance of the game.

To put the numbers in perceptive there are 25,000 schools such as those in Alexandra spread throughout South Africa!

From those humble beginnings we can develop a "Junior Cricket" league that can boast 20 regions with at least 10 Teams per region. Starting from  nothing we could have up to 500 aspirant Provincial and national Cricket team contenders - all with a HOPE and a DREAM that they are working at. The balance of the funds raised will be used to suitably kit out these players in their playing positions.

Many of these players will also have the desire to start their own schools, work as Instructors or establish fully fledged Academies further driving the vision. 

THIS IS NOT AN IMPOSSIBLE DREAM!!

This Vision is about putting the facilities and the support at the point of need. In the Townships at the schools that are waging up uphill battle to make education - in its broadest sense namely building the full person both Academically and as a member of society - because of a lack of interest and what is considered "non-essential" activity funding.

If we cannot meet the goal of establishing at least 5 regions the funding raised up to that point will be put into feeding schemes for the Rural underprivileged children who are not yet of school going age via already established NGO's and Charities. 

The Impact

If we do not arrest the rapid  downward spiral in lack of hope and opportunity for the under 15's in South Africa we will be faced with the worst nightmare of a society that with nothing to lose will turn in upon itself and destroy everything - whether it be good or bad. This new culture will lose all touch with the values that make a country and a people great - all focus will be on self gratification, domination, power and dominance. This tendency is blatantly apparent in our Gang scene in the Townships today. It will rapidly escalate the scenes we see in so many of our townships today where innocent babies are shot in their Mother's arm's and 3 and 4 year old children who are innocently playing on the sidewalk become the victims of gang war cross fire, children who are to afraid to go to school and a police and security force that cannot cope with the demands to protect them - this is a future that cannot be countenanced!!

TO GET A FIRST HAND IDEA OF WHAT THIS INITIATIVE IS AIMING TO ACHIEVE PLEASE VISIT       https://twitter.com/AlexChiefsCC  - THANKS.


Risks & Challenges

A large hurdle to overcome will be to break the hold of gangs and drug lords on the current crop of teenagers.

Fortunately society is already rising to that challenge with movement such as PAGAD in the Western Cape and large public protests in known drug lord areas in other cities.

A critical a aspect for the success of this venture will be the buy-in from the Police and other Security institutions and parents to ensure that when children elect to take the "high road" in their lives they are not intimidated and bullied and cajoled into abandoning their dream. This will require a great deal of "Town Hall" meetings and the establishment of security networks  and structures to provide the protection needed for those children that we want to be the catalyst for developing a brighter future for this entire country.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I hope that armed with this knowledge of what we MUST fight to win back our children you will share as widely as possible. Ask people you know who may have contacts into the  Cricket Equipment business or even just the ability to sew uniforms.

    Just help us by making people aware that we are not going to sit back and allow ruthlessly take control of the future of our children with disasterous consequences.
story_txt:
Short Summary
I am a South African by birth and have lived in this country for 60 years. During that time I was exposed to a number of ideologies and even went through the mandatory "brain washing" we called "Citizen Service" - an excuse to send a large number of my compatriots to fight wars that were senseless and only motivated by political agendas without any substance.
During my 20's I and my wife began to realize that what we saw going on around us was not how a normal Society should operate. We began to befriend a number of "non-white" people and became close friends with some of them. Probably the tipping point for us was the day we wanted to visit our one friend's new born in the "Location" and he told us that we would be arrested if the police found us there!! To cut a long story short we got him to smuggle us in and we gave the baby her gifts. 
As strange as it may sound after 20 years of "independence" we still see a crying need for the upliftment of people who had come from a culture where no real opportunities were available and where they cannot see any changes that which would engender hope in a better future for themselves but, most critically, their children. The upsurge in violent, destructive service delivery protest is evidence of this.
I and my team have decided that we need to take action and create a new environment for our younger generation within which they can see opportunities for self improvement and upliftment. story:
Hi, my name is Ken DeVaul. First let me say, the money raised will be donated to Cubit Foundation, a non-profit Christian humanitarian aid organization. The funds will be used to help feed, clothe and build shelter for children & orphans just outside the small town  of Valledupar,  Colombia, South America.  The people that run Cubit Foundation are good people; I've gone with Cubit Foundation to Haiti, Ecuador, Colombia and the Dominican Republic.  The heart of Cubit Foundation is to get the funds dispersed to those in need, not get eaten up in administrative cost.  Cubit Foundation knows how to maximize the use of funds. I've seen first-hand the work and help that Cubit Foundation has provided, and pray this campaign will inspire you to participate. 

Why combine weight loss and helping children?

My kids are grown now, but years ago they would come home from school with various school fundraisers. One fundraiser had the children run or walk around the school running track. Parents, family and friends would donate for every trip around the track in an effort to help the school. 

In a similar spirit, I've combined losing weight with helping orphans. Certainly helping orphans is more than a worthy cause in and of itself. The reason for combining losing weight  as an added incentive for helping Orphans, is that it makes the entire process more personal and gives extra incentive for all who participate.  Everyone knows losing weight is hard to do. If you are at all like me, you've tried multiple times to lose weight and have ultimately failed.  

Here's how it works: You pledge to donate $1, $5, $10 or more for every pound you lose during the campaign. It's that simple!

The reason failure is not an option this time, is that these children's needs are far greater than ours. I can't let them down, we together won't let them down. 

Please read excerpts from a letter from Brad Charles regarding his recent trip to Valledupar, Colombia.

Brad Charles’ Trip to Colombia – April 19-23, 2014

I originally came to Valledupar to check out an orphanage project.  My intentions were to come here, spend about $2000, and construct a water system for the orphanage.  But, once I got here I discovered that the real need was far greater than supplying pure water for an orphanage. The outlying areas of town is very similar to Egypt’s garbage cities. Four little communities are located here.  In these communities  live about 5000 people, more or less.  They don’t have anything.  I know this is the case in many parts of the world, if not most of the world. But what makes this horrible existence somewhat different than other similar tragedies is that my friend, Fernando pastors a church located right in the middle of this horrifying mess.  Fernando’s church is under the covering of Puerta de Salvation in Pereira. This place is quit a sight.  5000 people live in shacks made of tin or cardboard, or both, with filthy black poisonous dirt floors.  Electricity, when it is available at all, is only available for only one hour a day, and the water is “borrowed” from the government buildings that are located near the communities.

The greatest tragedy in this place is the kids.  The adults can usually fend for themselves and survive, but here, the kids have to also.  The children with parents are made to work in the streets.  This is common in 3rd world countries but its kinda shocking to see a mother drop her daughter off at a church service because the mom had to hit the streets to be able to pay for food that next day.  These kids sell drugs, they sell themselves, and the strangest thing is that they sell gas.  It sounds funny but where we are is 3 hours away from the Venezuelan border.  Many Colombians cross the border and buy gas there super cheap.  They bring the gas back illegally and sell the gas half the price of the gas at the pumps.  The kids sell the gas.

Then there are the orphans. They live in the streets, where they find a little hole to sleep in and look through trash for food. I want to help these kids more than anything. I've seen these kids with my own two eyes, 6-year-old kids looking through the trash for food. How I want to help them!

God bless you,


Brad Charles


After reading Brad's letter I felt humbled and shamed. The idea that I want to tie in losing weight in some ways is self serving. At the same time, obesity is a problem for our country and I'm not so proud that I reject any means possible, as long as they are legal and moral, in an effort to obtain the goals set forth in this campaign. In other words, I'm not above leveraging my American commercialism and vanity in an effort to win over the high road of pure caring and love.  I admit I'm weak and it takes something far beyond my will power to lose weight. It takes real human need and sacrifice, something that is a foreign concept to our glorious bountiful country.  

I admit, helping these children should be enough for all of us to donate. The reality is my family and friends would like me to lose weight. They care about me, they love me, they know that at my age, being overweight is dangerous and bad for my health. They know if I lose weight, the likelihood of me living longer increases. So, for them, me losing weight is added incentive, a bonus for those who care about me. Would they rather me be in perfect health and just twist their arm to help support young children in need? Of course. 

My weight loss for charity will be a personal, visual and physical representation of the children you will ultimately help. I'm a cause touch point if you will, with a Win Win double bonus. Seeing me thinner and helping needy children... honestly, the only way it gets any better, is if you join with me in the cause.  

Let's lose weight together and raise money to help the children in Valledupar, Colombia!

Please donate! If you can't donate, join with me in the cause by inspiring others to give, or do both. 

My goal is to lose 25 pounds during the 60 days this campaign is active. How much do you want to lose? Let's put our money where our mouth is, and use it to help these children.  

To read more about Cubit Foundation go to www.cubitfoundation.org. 

The video pictures are from a recent trip Brad Charles of Cubit Foundation took while in Valledupar. You can see in the photos the impoverished conditions and why your donation, however small or great, will make a significant impact on the lives of these children.

Thank you in advance for your help.

story:
Keep Hicham in school - Take 2!

Dearest friends and supporters,

We are back on Indiegogo because we need your help more than ever! Hicham has only 10 months left to his 3-year program, but I am at a point where I cannot support him by myself anymore. Any amount will help us both tremendously to make it through the next few months, as I am starting an apprenticeship program myself and will need to focus my finances on my own education. Please donate today, we really need your help!!!


Read on to learn the full story...

(Texte en français au bas de la page)


The story

In 2009, my travels led me to Morocco, where I was blessed to stay with a wonderful family and where I truly connected with a new brother, Hicham. Thanks to them, I felt nurtured in the midst of what became a big life transition. Through my unsettling culture shock, Hicham offered guidance and helped me to grow as an individual. Ever since then, we have kept contact like members of a real family. Today, my brother needs my help, but I cannot do it alone.

A little more about Hicham

Above all, Hicham is dedicated to offering local children accessible eye care and his greatest dream is to be of service in his hometown, near his parents and siblings, and start a family of his own.  Since I’ve known him, Hicham has used every opportunity to volunteer in his community and help anyone he is able to (including me).  A passionate and intelligent 29 year old, he is now focused on studying orthoptics, a type of vision therapy that has never been taught in Morocco before. As part of a pioneering cohort of students, he will work with children with eye muscle disorders, widening the range of treatment options where accessibility to healthcare can be a challenge.   

The financial reality

Amazingly, $320 USD/CAD per month pays for tuition, rent, food and transportation for Hicham while he’s studying in Rabat. He has tried everything to find funding, but things don’t work the same way in Morocco. There are no such things as student loans or student jobs. I have been the only one supporting him, besides our previous campaign. We are his only option now. Our goal is to raise enough for the next 3 months, while I will also be in school on my side of the world.

Why give today?

To help my brother, to help me, and to allow a dream to come true.  Once we have understood what it means to rely on another person during a trying time, we are eager to return the love that was shown to us.  With the solution at the tip of my fingers, I’m asking you to give today.  For him to be able to help kids in his community.  For him to have a family of his own. To pass along to others the kindnesses shown to us.

Every little bit helps!

Thank you sincerely

_____________________________________________

Gardons Hicham à l’école - 2e prise

Il ne pourra pas compléter ses études sans nous!

L’histoire

En 2009, mes voyages m’ont emmenée au Maroc, où j’ai eu la chance d’être accueillie par une famille exceptionnelle et où je me suis liée d’une amitié fraternelle avec Hicham. Grâce à eux, j’ai reçu tout le support dont j’ai eu besoin au milieu de ce qui est devenu une grande transition dans ma vie. Hicham a agit comme un frère pour moi, offrant son soutien durant ce choc culturel et transformationnel, et il m’a vraiment aidée à évoluer en tant que personne. Nous sommes toujours restés en contact comme les membres d’une véritable famille. Aujourd’hui, mon frère marocain a vraiment besoin de mon aide, mais je ne peux y arriver toute seule.

Au sujet d’Hicham

Par dessus tout, Hicham est dédié à rendre accessible les soins des yeux aux enfants de sa communauté et son plus grand rêve est de le faire dans sa ville natale, là où il veut fonder sa propre famille auprès de ses parents et de ses frères et sœurs. Depuis que je le connais, il a toujours su maximiser chaque opportunité de pouvoir aider les autres en dévouant son temps et son soutien autant que possible, tout comme il l’a fait pour moi. Hicham est un jeune homme passionné et intelligent, maintenant sérieusement concentré sur ses études en orthoptie. Une pratique nouvellement enseignée au Maroc, il s’agit d’un secteur de l'ophtalmologie qui étudie et traite les troubles visuels par rééducation. Faisant partie du premier groupe d’étudiants en ce domaine, Hicham travaillera avec les enfants qui ont des problèmes de vision, aidant à rendre ce type the thérapie plus accessible à tous.

La réalité financière

Hicham a besoin de seulement 300$ USD/CAN par mois pour couvrir tous les frais liés à ses études, incluant les frais de scolarité, le logement, la nourriture ainsi que le transport. Hicham a fait beaucoup d’efforts afin de trouver les sommes requises pour pouvoir compléter ses études, mais les choses fonctionnent bien différemment au Maroc. Il n’y a pas de programmes de support aux études tel que des prêts et bourses ou même du travail pour les étudiants, comme chez nous. Nous sommes sa seule option à ce point. Notre but est d'amasser assez d'argent pour les trois prochains mois alors que je serai aussi a l'ecole de mon cote du globe.


Pourquoi donner aujourd’hui?

Pour aider mon frère, pour m’aider moi et pour aider à ce que le rêve d’Hicham devienne réalité. Parce que nous avons reçu l’aide inestimable d’une personne durant des moments difficiles de notre vie, nous comprenons l’importance d’être là pour s’aider les uns les autres. Avec cette solution au bout de nos doigts, je vous demande de contribuer dès aujourd’hui pour qu’Hicham puisse aider les enfants de sa communauté. Pour qu’il puisse fonder sa propre famille. Pour partager avec les autres la bonté qui nous a été offerte.

Merci sincèrement!

tremendously to make it through the next few months, as I am starting an
apprenticeship program myself and will need to focus my finances on my own
education. Please donate today, we really need your help!!!
Read on to learn the full story... (Texte en français au bas de la page)





The story
In 2009, my travels led me to Morocco, where I was blessed to stay 
with a wonderful family and where I truly connected with a new brother, 
Hicham. Thanks to them, I felt nurtured in the midst of what became a 
big life transition. Through my unsettling culture shock, Hicham offered
 guidance and helped me to grow as an individual. Ever since then, we 
have kept contact like members of a real family. Today, my brother needs
 my help, but I cannot do it alone.
A little more about Hicham
Above all, Hicham is dedicated to offering local children accessible 
eye care and his greatest dream is to be of service in his hometown, 
near his parents and siblings, and start a family of his own.  Since 
I’ve known him, Hicham has used every opportunity to volunteer in his 
community and help anyone he is able to (including me).  A passionate 
and intelligent 29 year old, he is now focused on studying orthoptics, a
 type of vision therapy that has never been taught in Morocco before. As
 part of a pioneering cohort of students, he will work with children 
with eye muscle disorders, widening the range of treatment options where
 accessibility to healthcare can be a challenge.   
The financial reality
Amazingly, $320 USD/CAD per month pays for tuition, rent, food and 
transportation for Hicham while he’s studying in Rabat. He has tried 
everything to find funding, but things don’t work the same way in 
Morocco. There are no such things as student loans or student jobs. I have been the only one supporting him, besides our previous campaign. We are his only option now. Our goal is to raise enough for the next 3 months, while I will also be in school on my side of the world. 
Why give today? 
To help my brother, to help me, and to allow a dream to come true. 
 Once we have understood what it means to rely on another person during a
 trying time, we are eager to return the love that was shown to us. 
 With the solution at the tip of my fingers, I’m asking you to give 
today.  For him to be able to help kids in his community.  For him to 
have a family of his own. To pass along to others the kindnesses shown 
to us.
Every little bit helps!
Thank you sincerely
_____________________________________________
Gardons Hicham à l’école - 2e prise

Il ne pourra pas compléter ses études sans nous!


L’histoire
En 2009, mes voyages m’ont emmenée au Maroc, où j’ai eu la chance 
d’être accueillie par une famille exceptionnelle et où je me suis liée 
d’une amitié fraternelle avec Hicham. Grâce à eux, j’ai reçu tout le 
support dont j’ai eu besoin au milieu de ce qui est devenu une grande 
transition dans ma vie. Hicham a agit comme un frère pour moi, offrant 
son soutien durant ce choc culturel et transformationnel, et il m’a 
vraiment aidée à évoluer en tant que personne. Nous sommes toujours 
restés en contact comme les membres d’une véritable famille. 
Aujourd’hui, mon frère marocain a vraiment besoin de mon aide, mais je 
ne peux y arriver toute seule.
Au sujet d’Hicham
Par dessus tout, Hicham est dédié à rendre accessible les soins des 
yeux aux enfants de sa communauté et son plus grand rêve est de le faire
 dans sa ville natale, là où il veut fonder sa propre famille auprès de 
ses parents et de ses frères et sœurs. Depuis que je le connais, il a 
toujours su maximiser chaque opportunité de pouvoir aider les autres en 
dévouant son temps et son soutien autant que possible, tout comme il l’a
 fait pour moi. Hicham est un jeune homme passionné et intelligent, 
maintenant sérieusement concentré sur ses études en orthoptie. Une 
pratique nouvellement enseignée au Maroc, il s’agit d’un secteur de 
l'ophtalmologie qui étudie et traite les troubles visuels par 
rééducation. Faisant partie du premier groupe d’étudiants en ce domaine,
 Hicham travaillera avec les enfants qui ont des problèmes de vision, 
aidant à rendre ce type the thérapie plus accessible à tous.
La réalité financière
Hicham a besoin de seulement 300$ USD/CAN par mois pour couvrir tous 
les frais liés à ses études, incluant les frais de scolarité, le 
logement, la nourriture ainsi que le transport. Hicham a fait beaucoup 
d’efforts afin de trouver les sommes requises pour pouvoir compléter ses
 études, mais les choses fonctionnent bien différemment au Maroc. Il n’y
 a pas de programmes de support aux études tel que des prêts et bourses 
ou même du travail pour les étudiants, comme chez nous. Nous sommes sa seule option à ce point. Notre but est d'amasser assez d'argent pour les trois prochains mois alors que je serai aussi a l'ecole de mon cote du globe. 
Pourquoi donner aujourd’hui?
Pour aider mon frère, pour m’aider moi et pour aider à ce que le rêve d’Hicham devienne réalité. Parce
 que nous avons reçu l’aide inestimable d’une personne durant des 
moments difficiles de notre vie, nous comprenons l’importance d’être là 
pour s’aider les uns les autres. Avec cette solution au bout de nos 
doigts, je vous demande de contribuer dès aujourd’hui pour qu’Hicham 
puisse aider les enfants de sa communauté. Pour qu’il puisse fonder sa 
propre famille. Pour partager avec les autres la bonté qui nous a été 
offerte. 
Merci sincèrement!

story:
Who We Are // Meet Valentina

Valentina is a former Italian field hockey player with a master in Psychology who is now working in the International Cooperation Sector in Tanzania. In this area there are several problems regarding education, health and women empowerment among others, and sports can be an opportunity to step forward in creating a better future for people. Valentina is based in Dar es Salaam since the end of January 2013, with an only dream in mind: “Bringing the Tanzanian Ladies Field Hockey National team to Kenya”. It all started when she met people playing field hockey in the streets in her previous experiences in Tanzania back in 2012. Last April the Dar es Salaam Hockey Association re-introduced the hockey school programme, utilizing the equipment that arrived from Italy (thanks to Valentina), aimed at promoting field hockey among youth. Besides, in May the Tanzanian Hockey Association asked Valentina to coach the Female National Team in order to participate in the African Nation Cup that will be held in Nairobi, Kenya, from September the 26th  to October the 6th 2013. She accepted immediately: “As a former national team player, coaching a national team is just a dream that could come true!!”. So they started to gather all the girls and to train everyday in the morning at Lugalo Hockey Field.

What We Need & What You Get

Although field hockey has been played in Tanzania since the early 20th Century, nowadays it’s still not as popular as other sports in the country. In the whole country there are few men teams and only one female team, which is also the national team. In the last years the Tanzanian Hockey Association has chosen to support the males team to, destining to them the poor resources offered by the Government to the “minority” sports.  But today the Tanzanian Ladies National team has the chance to participate in Africa Nation Cup, a tournament that is valid as a Qualifier for the 2014 World Cup. This prestigious competition will be hosted in Nairobi from September the 26th to October the 6th 2013. The Tanzanian Hockey Association hasn’t got funds for this, so is looking for support in order to be able to cover the costs related to the participation in the tournament, such as tournament fee, travel fees to Nairobi or accommodation for two weeks abroad. For doing so, 10.000€ are needed.

If you can only give 20€, or 10€, or even 1€ it will truly make a difference. A little goes a long way, and every cent will be greatly appreciated.

The Impact

Many times the Tanzanian Ladies team was supposed to participate to international competitions in other African countries such as Kenya, Uganda, where hockey is more developed and widespread. But they always failed to go because of the lack of money from sponsor.

If we achieve our goal, for the Ladies Team will be the first time to represent their country in an official international competition!

The present campaign has the purpose to present our challenge to go to Nairobi and we truly hope that some of our friends worldwide will help us to achieve  our dream. And yes, YOU can help with our case and make an impact.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends!

If you can’t contribute to the cause, please help by getting the word out. Post this on your facebook, youtube and twitter accounts. Send this to friends, coworkers, or someone you know who can help or support us. 

Sponsor in kind or Volunteer!

If you would like to sponsor in kind or volunteer, please write us at hockeytanzania@gmail.com. We’d love to hear from you!

For More Information

For more information about the project please visit the website: http://hockeytanzania.wordpress.com

You can find the latest news about the project and bios of the players! :-)

 

We sincerely appreciate all of your continued support and love.

Asante sana (many thanks in Swahilian)!

story:
This Project

Help us launch our next youth and public arts project designed to take place in two Malian refugee camps in the Sahel of Niger from September to December 2013. Called Energizing Refugee Communities Through Art, we created this project in order to share the power of art with refugee communities, knowing that there are few opportunities for self-expression and cultural representation in refugee camps. 

Malian youth in Abala Refugee Camp 2013 PHOTO: courtesy of ACTED


The Malian refugee crisis began in early 2012, when violent conflict in Mali forced thousands of Malian men, women and children to leave their homes and flee across the border into Niger where they have been housed in multiple refugee camps. Colors of Connection will work with 36 youth to create murals in public spaces in two of these camps: Abala which houses approximately 13,000 refugees and Mangaizé, home to 7,000. 

The Impact:

Our project will encourage 36 Malian youths' capacity for personal achievement through self-expression and creativity, while enhancing their civic interest and engagement and fostering their role as positive contributors to society. In addition, we will train a youth artist in each camp on how to teach and execute a community arts project to increase sustainability and use of the arts in Abala and Mangaizé Camps. Lastly, the murals that will be created in Mangaizé and Abala Refugee Camps will affirm the hopes and dreams of the 20,000 Malian refugees in Abala and Mangaizé Refugee Camps.

Colors of Connection is a youth arts organization that enables connections between people and communities through creative expression. 


This project has been approved by the United Nations refugee agency, UNHCR, and has been positively reviewed by the refugee populations in Abala and Mangaizé Refugee Camps.


In these two refugee camps where the focus is solely on survival, we believe that this project will bring a special therapeutic energy that will help people believe in more than their immediate reality and imagine a positive future. It will allow them to connect with each other through their common hopes and dreams and focus on what’s most important to them.

What We Need & What You Get

The total project budget is $27,500. We are thrilled that our partners who manage Abala and Mangaizé Refugee Camps, Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development (ACTED)  and Islamic Relief Worldwide (IRW), will support logistical and transportation expenses of $12,600. Your support will cover a part of the remaining costs which includes supplies for mural painting $2,100, youth participant expenses $500, administrative expenses $2,150 and contingency $1,200. If we make the 6k goal we have set on Indiegogo, we will reach 65% of our total budget and are optimistic that through grants and other support we will be able to launch this project at the end of September.
Our perks include matching you with one of the 36 vulnerable refugee youth we work with and updating you on their growth and development during the project. Other perks are drawings sent to you and created by these youth, photographs of the project and even having your name on one of the murals!    

The Difference Your Contribution Will Make

 As is the case in humanitarian emergencies, aid agencies focus on the basic needs and opportunities for creative development are rare to non-existent. However in situations of crisis like this one, creative energy can help to meet the severe psychological challenges that refugees experience, including displacement, cultural bereavement, and disruption of community and social support networks. Community arts projects like the ones Colors of Connection will carry out can introduce activities that build vibrant civil society, portray values and culture, provide a platform for self-representation, and help to address psychological adversities in the lives of refugees.

How

During these three months, we will create a local community arts council in each camp and bring together 18 youth (9 girls and 9 boys) from each camp. Together we will mobilize to transform these refugee camps into environments which express the hopes and dreams for the future of Malian Refugees through the creation of 2 murals. 36 youth will be given bi-weekly classes in the arts which will incorporate arts activities aimed at addressing the psychosocial needs and adversities that they face. These youth will have the opportunity to engage creatively in transforming their camp communities. Because older youth in refugee camps around the world receive less services and support from government and aid agencies than younger youth, we will work with female and male youth aged 12-18 in these camps.

About Us

Established in 2010, Colors of Connection is a youth arts organization that enables connections between people and communities through creative expression. The mission of the organization is to nurture hope, well-being and development in disadvantaged youth and societies worldwide through community-based art and through advocacy for art in education.
We have successfully completed 3 projects including a public art and youth project called Vision of Hope in which we worked with 56 school children to complete four themed murals in public spaces in the war torn town of Harper, Liberia. This project will be featured in the upcoming documentary Beyond the Walls, and was funded in part by the International Foundation. Colors of Connection also completed a public arts project with 30 out of school Ivorian youth in Little Wlebo Refugee Camp in Liberia commissioned by the Danish Refugee Council. Find out more at: www.colorsofconnection.org.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, spread the word about this campaign because sharing WILL help us reach our goal!

story:
Short Summary

The focus of my business (www.FamilyStrongBirth.com) has evolved as I grew into my role as a mother and as an advocate in the birth field. My doula role has been as a family advocate, educator, cheerleader and companion. The fathers and children have been equally important to me. In most cases, the mamas have chosen to secure a doula for the sake of their family. Mamas want to be nurtured, but I have found that to allow herself to truly surrender to the power of her pregnancy and birth, she must feel her family is taken care of first. What I hold firmly in my heart is that the family unit deserves to be respected and embraced. Thereby, as their choices are presented from moment to moment, they are increasingly gaining strength and confidence in their ability to choose what is best for them at this present time in their lives. 

Midwifery promotes just that: safe options in family centered child birth & women's health care. As a student of the Massachusetts Midwives Alliance Basic Course in Midwifery, I will be mentored by highly skilled midwives from across the state. A second program, Ancient Arts Midwifery Institute, offers students a comprehensive online course in advanced studies. Didactic education will be supplemented by an apprenticeship under preceptor midwives. Upon graduation from the program and apprenticeship, I will be eligible to take the national certification examination to earn my licensure to practice as a home birth midwife. 

What I Need & What You Get

Tuition, books, supplies, tools & transportation and/or childcare expenses totals over $5000. Our family consists of two working parents both furthering their education. We are appreciative of any donation/gift provided to assist me in my goal. I am asking for help reaching the balance of $4250.00. I am offering doula support and placenta encapsulation services in exchange for assistance. This option can be purchased as a gift certificate, however all monies gratefully received are non-refundable. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share my fundraising campaign with other friends and family by using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Promote out of hospital birth by following the Massachusetts Midwives Alliance online and at their public events!
  • Talk about birth with your children, cousins, siblings, parents, friends, neighbors, colleagues, politicians, medical providers, etc. Normalize birth by learning, trusting and sharing the beauty and power of it.

story:
Odyssey of the Mind is a creative problem-solving competition involving students from kindergarten through high school. Our team is a problem 4, division 3 team from Gulf High School. In problem 4, teams will design and build a structure made of only balsa wood and glue, and it will be tested by balancing and supporting weights after it is stacked. The structure must be an artistic representation of the Earth. A performance will integrate the artistic representation and the weight placing.

  Our team is from Gulf High School, consisting of the IB students Emily Crouch, Jamie Graves, Amanda Topper, Shane Gillen, Jody Mitchell, and David Graniero. Our performance focuses around the creation myth of the Greek gods and goddesses. We placed first at the regional competition and second at the state competition.

  As seniors in high school, this is our first and last chance to attend the world competition. Teams from all around the world will be competing, and it is a great opportunity to meet new, foreign friends.

  However, there are significant travel and lodging costs. For our entire team, and our coach, it will be about $10,000. We have multiple fundraising opportunities set-up, but will still need significant backing in order to attend the world competition.
