story:
Synopsis

Hi! My name is Yasunori Numakoshi. I'm a book producer in Japan. I have worked in publishing for many years and really enjoy creating fun ways for people to learn English conversation. One of the books I produced in rencet years was ranked #3 in the amazon.com English conversation section.

You can find it here:

http://www.amazon.co.jp/gp/product/4048709356?ie=UTF8&tag=asciicorp-22&linkCode=as2&camp=247&creative=1211&

 

This winter we'd like to produce an English pronunciation book in one of my favorite American Cities, Seattle. To make this the most unique and engaging book for the Japanese audience we are working with beautiful and intelegent American women to teach everyday English conversation. It may sound common place in the States, but in Japan everyone loves to hear smart, beautiful American women speak. Both men and women are very interested to learn about they way American women speak and the body langauge they use in daily conversation. For years too the books have been dry, overly academic, and not aknowledged the use of the face, body, and vocal tone in English communication. This also makes for a much more entertaining experience for the students! We aim to entertain! 

 

Our Vision

In Japan, English is not seen as entertainment; people only think of it as education. This is one reason most Japanese can’t speak English. It’s not fun and they give up learning it. So we'd like to make English more fun, natural, and easy to get into. Our previous book project got ranked #3 on Amazon's "English conversation" section. That book was a series of real interviews with Americans - natural, unscripted, and quite funny! With this book we saw the Japanese perceptions of English studying begin to change, but we can do more!

The Japanese people have come to realize how important pronunciation is speaking fluidly. Correctly pronouncing English is tough but rewarding for Japanese people. Knowing how to correctly say the words you have studied enables you to communicate with people all over the globe. We have heard countless stories of Japanese people who could not communicate well with Westerners in English, despite considerable study in English, due mainly to their inability to pronounce and hear words. We think this is because pronunciation is seen as a chore. Through working with amazing American women we can get people interested in pronunciation and assist students in becoming better all around converationalists. We really want to make this a fun and rewarding experience. We know that both men and women will enjoy this product, and help them have fun as they study!

Our book sold at the book stores all over the Japan, as well as major internet retailers. We will also send our book to rouhgly 100 Japanese media sources including major magazines and TV companies. All we need in the means to make the content. That is why we are coming to you. 

 

What we need 

Producing a book and DVD is not cheap! We have to work with a lot of professionals, such as a cameraman, photographer, sound tech, casting agency, coordinators, and models. We also need to rent the camera, sound equipment, and other expensive tools! Our team typically produces these books with a combination of our own funds and help from the publisher. Sadly, Japanese publishers do not see the need for students to learn from an actual American person. We want to prove to them that seeing and hearing Americans will help students get better. It is also a great way to get Japanese people to become comfortable with hearing Americans talk. So this time we want to partner with you!

Here’s what we need:

space rental

camera rental

light rental

sound rental

casting (cameraman,photographer, professor, sound tech, light tech, models etc)

editing

sound effects

promotion & marketing

 

For your support, your name can be included in the book. You

can have a title (such as “”Adviser" or Executive Producer"), and

you could even show up on the DVD. All of this can be used

to further your career and can be added to your resume.

 

So we're looking forward to your help!
story_txt:
Synopsis
Hi! My name is Yasunori Numakoshi. I'm a book producer in Japan. I have worked in publishing for many years and really enjoy creating fun ways for people to learn English conversation. One of the books I produced in rencet years was ranked #3 in the amazon.com English conversation section.
You can find it here:
http://www.amazon.co.jp/gp/product/4048709356?ie=UTF8&tag=asciicorp-22&linkCode=as2&camp=247&creative=1211&
 
This winter we'd like to produce an English pronunciation book in one of my favorite American Cities, Seattle. To make this the most unique and engaging book for the Japanese audience we are working with beautiful and intelegent American women to teach everyday English conversation. It may sound common place in the States, but in Japan everyone loves to hear smart, beautiful American women speak. Both men and women are very interested to learn about they way American women speak and the body langauge they use in daily conversation. For years too the books have been dry, overly academic, and not aknowledged the use of the face, body, and vocal tone in English communication. This also makes for a much more entertaining experience for the students! We aim to entertain! 
 
Our Vision
In Japan, English is not seen as entertainment; people only think of it as education. This is one reason most Japanese can’t speak English. It’s not fun and they give up learning it. So we'd like to make English more fun, natural, and easy to get into. Our previous book project got ranked #3 on Amazon's "English conversation" section. That book was a series of real interviews with Americans - natural, unscripted, and quite funny! With this book we saw the Japanese perceptions of English studying begin to change, but we can do more!
The Japanese people have come to realize how important pronunciation is speaking fluidly. Correctly pronouncing English is tough but rewarding for Japanese people. Knowing how to correctly say the words you have studied enables you to communicate with people all over the globe. We have heard countless stories of Japanese people who could not communicate well with Westerners in English, despite considerable study in English, due mainly to their inability to pronounce and hear words. We think this is because pronunciation is seen as a chore. Through working with amazing American women we can get people interested in pronunciation and assist students in becoming better all around converationalists. We really want to make this a fun and rewarding experience. We know that both men and women will enjoy this product, and help them have fun as they study!
Our book sold at the book stores all over the Japan, as well as major internet retailers. We will also send our book to rouhgly 100 Japanese media sources including major magazines and TV companies. All we need in the means to make the content. That is why we are coming to you. 
 
What we need 
Producing a book and DVD is not cheap! We have to work with a lot of professionals, such as a cameraman, photographer, sound tech, casting agency, coordinators, and models. We also need to rent the camera, sound equipment, and other expensive tools! Our team typically produces these books with a combination of our own funds and help from the publisher. Sadly, Japanese publishers do not see the need for students to learn from an actual American person. We want to prove to them that seeing and hearing Americans will help students get better. It is also a great way to get Japanese people to become comfortable with hearing Americans talk. So this time we want to partner with you!
Here’s what we need:
space rental
camera rental
light rental
sound rental
casting (cameraman,photographer, professor, sound tech, light tech, models etc)
editing
sound effects
promotion & marketing
 
For your support, your name can be included in the book. You
can have a title (such as “”Adviser" or Executive Producer"), and
you could even show up on the DVD. All of this can be used
to further your career and can be added to your resume.
 
So we're looking forward to your help!

story:
Our students are going to change the world.

But we won't be able to open our doors without your help. 

As a free public school, we don't receive our state funding until November, so this fundraiser will create the bridge to allow us to open our doors and operate until then. 

Read below for more information about how crucial your contribution is to our school and to learn more about the incredible amount of good that we can ONLY do with your help.

Why we need your help:

  • Detroit Achievement Academy is a free public school and is therefore funded by the great State of Michigan. 
  • The State doesn't send us our first (small) piece of funding until November.
  • But our first day of school is in September.
  • It costs a bunch of money to start and run a great school until November!


What we will use the money to do:

  • STAFF. We will pay our teachers, administrators, and classroom assistants.

  • FACILITIES. We will pay our rent and utilities bills.

  • CLASSROOM MATERIALS. We will buy desks, pencils, and joyful, print-rich learning aids to hang in our classrooms.


Pretty simple, right? We will certainly have plenty of other startup costs, but we have used our business and negotiating chops to structure them to fall after we begin receiving state funding or when we are likely to receive various other grants. Essentially, we are only asking for what we absolutely need in order to be able to open our doors to our students this fall.


Here are the basics about Detroit Achievement Academy: 

  • We are starting with 50 Kindergarten students and 50 1st grade students. We'll add a grade level each year; our students move up and we will take new classes of Kindergarten.
  • We will be located on the northwest side of Detroit, in the Grandmont-Rosedale neighborhood.
  • We have all approvals and authorizations to operate as a school.
  • Our authorizer is Grand Valley State University. They are nationally respected for the success of their schools. 

 

But we aren't starting a school to do things
the way that they are currently being done. 

 


Here is how we are different: 

  • Our Principal, Sharon Yaecker Roesser, is seriously incredible. She has 12 years experience in education as a teacher, a social worker, and school leader in schools in New York City and Detroit. Essentially, her life's work has been removing obstacles for students and families as they move along their paths toward their own hopes and dreams.
  • Our curriculum, Expeditionary Learning, is project-based, with learning standards focused on the Common Core. Schools that use Expeditionary Learning outperform other schools in their district by 12%. A study done in NYC found that EL schools "closed the gap" in English Language Arts for African-American, Hispanic, and low-income students and English language learners.
  • We will feed our students three balanced meals a day. We believe that our students should know what they are eating, from where it came, and how and by whom it was grown. DAA will use food as a tool to teach everything from geography to social studies to math.
  • We will have a full-time Director of Family & Student Support, who will coordinate services and assistance to our familes, facilitate community meetings, and generally serve as an advocate for our families and neighborhood.
  • We will have heavy amounts of community programming. It is a top priority for us to be a part of the fabric of our neighborhood and community.
  • We will foster our visual and performing arts program and use it to enrich our school culture and our daily classroom activities. 
  • We believe our students deserve to learn from experts. Every Wednesday at 1:30pm, our students will be released from their classes to a Master Class. During this time, our classroom teachers will meet, plan, and collaborate. Our students will then receive a lesson and complete projects with experts from a wide range of industries. Our Master Classes will include everything from a introduction to code and programming to Aztec dance to saving seeds from vegetables. We believe that exposing our students to both cutting edge and traditional practices and ideas will empower them as they create their own path, with their own interests and talents. 


What you get for helping us out:

We want to show you how much we appreciate your help, so we developed some fun perks for our donors! 

Like our Thank You Art. The balloons will be fingerprints from the first day of school.

And our Seed Packet. These seeds will be the same seeds we use in our classrooms, in our gardens, to send home to families, etc. They will come from the various seed cooperatives in Detroit and other southeast Michigan farmers.

 

And of course, our DAA T-shirt. These will be what our students wear (though often with long sleeves) and our friends have been asking for them since they saw the smaller versions. We would love to see them on our donors!

 

And, our most coveted piece of DAA gear, the DAA Sweatshirts. These are soft, cozy, and will be exclusive to our Indiegogo backers. That's right, these are awesome AND limited edition.

       

 

We can't wait to have you all involved with Detroit Achievement Academy!  Check out ALL the ways you can help on the right!

We can't wait to send you your thank you gifts. 

Thank you for helping us open our school!

--------

Have a question?

E-mail us at hello@detroitachievement.org. We will respond as fast as we can (likely with lots of smiley faces and exclamation points.)

-------- 

Video and Perks Credits:

We had the absolute honor of working with some talented folks as we prepared our fundraising campaign.

All DAA Perks were designed by the amazing AME Atelier.

Video:

Dante Marshall, The Art Direction, Executive Producer

Ryan Burbank, Director of Photography & Post Production

Adrian Champion, Brand New Classic, Director & Producer

G'Oni Jones, Director of Photography

story:
What's this Trip All About?

The trip focuses on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We will be meeting with experts in DC and NYC as well as throughout Israel, the West Bank, and Jordan. The trip is organized and facilitated by the Olive Tree Initiative, which aims to give students exposure to every dimension of international conflict through first-hand experience.

  • The delegation will be composed of about 20 undergraduates from UC Berkeley and Stanford as well as several graduate students from San Diego State University.
  • The trip will take place from July 28th to August 18th. 
  • We will spend several days on the east coast meeting with American experts and officials before departing to the Middle East.
  • Once we arrive in the Middle East, we will be crossing borders every few days, traveling throughout the region to meet with local leaders and touring sites relevant to the history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.  
  • Last summer, OTI students met with representatives from the White House, U.S. Department of State, various congressional offices, the United Nations, Human Rights Watch, World Economic Forum, Israeli Knesset, Palestinian Legislative Council, the Jordanian royal family, and many other prominent organizations. 

Why I NEED your help:

I can't do this without you. International travel is expensive, and while I will be paying for much of the cost, I won't be able to go without the support of friends and family. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity that I won't be able to take without your help. All funds donated will go toward travel expenses (airfare, hotels, buses, etc.)

Why does this opportunity matter?

As a student of political science and history, I've studied the history of the Middle East, European History, Conflict & Religion, and Comparative Politics; I plan on pursuing a career in public service. However, in-class learning isn't enough to truly understand the realities of international politics. First hand exposure is the only way to understand the realities of this kind of conflict. This trip would be a life changing experience for me. 

 

 

For more information on the Olive Tree Initiative:

www.olivetreeinitiative.com

 

For a copy of last year's trip itinerary: 

http://www.olivetreeinitiative.org/middle_east_travel

 

For a video describing last year's trip:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i3x7RKfY6ks

 

I would greatly appreciate any donations you can provide.

story:
UPDATE: THE AMOUNT NEEDED FOR MY FEES HAS BEEN REACHED! I'm so, so grateful to everyone for this. After asking Twitter, I've decided to leave this campaign open: in all of the student finance awfulness, they also stripped me of a £3,000 maintenance grant that I should be using to support my family and my time in university - they assessed me as NEEDING it, then cut it away. I didn't think I'd have time or the reach to raise this money, but the campaign is being left open until its closing date in order for people who wish to donate and make the amount I'm missing out on a little smaller able to do so. I love you all so much. Thank you for being here.


A few months ago, we raised almost £3k through a previous campaign. Although it wasn't anywhere near the full amount I needed, it was a really good start to paying my fees. I started university and the £9000 for the fees is due in April. Due to a magnificent show of generosity by a close friend, the amount went up by £5,000. That means that there is £1,500 left to pay on my fees, and I need it in the next two-three weeks. The amount aiming to be raised here reflects the charges IndieGoGo take from the amount raised, plus the £1500 required. If you know me and my situation, that’s all you need to know. If you don’t, have a read below. This is mostly the information posted on the original fundraiser, with some small changes to reflect changes in my life.

I really believe we can raise this money. Every donation honestly does help, and a significant amount of the money we raised last time came from small donations, so if you can spare £5, or £1, please don't think it's not worth giving.

Thank you for reading.

Hi. I'm Dorian. I assume you know who I am, but if by some miracle this reaches further: I am 24 years old. I live with my wife and our 2yo son.

I started university when I was 19, and I had a nervous breakdown 3 months in. I failed university, ran out of money, and found out I was pregnant. I assumed I'd never be able to go back.

Last year I went out on a limb and applied to do the course I've wanted to do since a child, Archaeology at Manchester. I got an unconditional offer. I dared to dream of a way to support my family, despite being severely disabled, and then Student Finance dashed those dreams again.

I now have an unholy number of diagnoses. I have Major Depressive Disorder, Generalised Anxiety Disorder, Panic Disorder, Borderline Personality Disorder, Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, Hypermobility, Chronic Fatigue, and a series of gastrointestinal problems caused by these other conditions and the medications I take for them. I am a wheelchair user and can't walk more than 50 metres. Because of how disabled I am, my wife is my full-time carer. She cannot work, and as such we live off a variety of state benefits designed to support families in our position. We have nothing left over at the end of the month – the safety net of the benefit state is hanging precariously low to the ground. In December, the government decided that I had too much money, and cut our income support. I’m now supporting all three of us on my meagre student loan. We cannot find spare money.

Student Finance have decided not to award me a tuition fee loan for this year. I have two years of funding remaining with them, but they are only willing to fund years 2 and 3 of my course. Their basis for this is the (incredibly disablist) assumption that I may, again, be thwarted by disability and then they'd have spent more money on me. I have appealed their decision, again and again, but they refuse to listen.

They have also assessed me as needing a £3,000 maintenance grant, but have since stripped me of it and sent me a bill for £800 to make up for my maintenance grant from the year I was 19. This is not money I have, and makes going to university and supporting my family incredibly difficult.

One of the ways to gain funding back is to prove that my previous failure was the result of ill health. Unfortunately, thanks to the horrible GP that I had at the time, my records are missing. I spent an hour going through them with my current GP. I sent them every piece of evidence I had, and they've declared it inadequate.

I was supposed to be starting University, with appropriate support for the first time in September. Instead I have had to scrape through on the bottom of my savings, with regular long panics about how it will all come to nothing if I cannot raise this obscene amount of money. I am so scared that I will lose any chance of this opportunity thanks to bureaucracy and disablism. My health is plummeting with the worry of it all. Everything hinges on this.

There are so many stresses pressing down on us at the moment, that this is the only way I can see forward. If everyone who follows me on Twitter were able to chuck in 50p, then I'd be able to pay my fees for this year. I wouldn't have to give up my dream. Even if they weren't, the more I'm able to get, the more likely I might be to persuade charities or the university to make up the rest.

The target here represents a replacement of the money that Student Finance have denied me for being disabled. If we can reach it, I can go to university. That would, at the moment, be more than I could ever imagine.

Any money raised in excess of this, tbh, is beyond my comprehension, but if the unthinkable occurs, it will go towards paying for my specialist equipment, my powerchair and our dire housing situation - especially in order to replace the grant that Student Finance cut.

Thank you so much for even reading this.

story:
Please select the perk you want (to the right) for more information and to claim it.

Note: want to make a donation instead of receiving a perk?  Click the red "Back It " button instead.

UPDATE: GREAT news!  In the past week we have raised over $7,000 for JVTF After School programs through this campaign.  Vulcan Materials Company Foundation has agreed to match up to $10,000 so please continue spreading the word to help us reach that goal - we are only $3,000 away!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thank you for your interest in the Jones Valley Teaching Farm "POWER OF FOOD" Giving Campaign.  Our goal is to raise $10,000 to cover a portion of the costs for our two after school programs: Farm Club and Student-Run Market.

  1. Farm Club: Farm Club after school programs provide an opportunity for students to become stewards of their school's Teaching Farm.  They help maintain the outdoor classroom and prepare food with the produce they have grown.  All classes are led by a Jones Valley Teaching Farm instructor.
  2. Student-Run Market: Each Fall and Spring, teams of students sell produce to their teachers, parents, and community members at each school site.  Through an accompanying curriculum, students learn new math skills and best practices in running their own small business, while providing direct access to produce, fruit, and flowers.

Many thanks to Vulcan Materials Company Foundation for matching every dollar donated to Jones Valley Teaching Farm through this campaign, which doubles your impact!

  • We educate over 20,000 students through our Teaching Farms (4,000 annually)
  • We grow over 18,000 pounds of fresh produce across seven teaching farms annually
  • Six of our Teaching Farm are located on Birmingham City Schools’ campuses
  • We host over 800 lessons per year
  • We lead 80 Student-Run Markets at six Teaching Farms every school year

If you are unable to give, financially, we understand and would love your support in spreading the word about our campaign.  Lots more information at www.jvtf.org.

story:
Team Members from Project DaVinci, a team of high school students in North Idaho launching a satellite with NASA. 

 

DaVinci Satellite--Inspiring STEM in Orbit:

Project DaVinci is a team of high school students in rural North Idaho working with the community’s best mentors to launch the DaVinci Satellite! As the only high school chosen by NASA to participate in the 7th round of the CubeSat Launch Initiative Program (CSLI), the team is looking to connect everyone to space again. The team has recognized the lack of enthusiasm shown towards space in the recent years and aims to give students around the world a personal connection with space once more.

Students at North Idaho STEM Charter Academy practice listening to other satellites, much like the DaVinci satellite. 

 

DaVinci's Mission:

The main focus of Project DaVinci is to inspire students around the world to pursue STEM education and careers. The team’s goal is to connect with at least one student from every country in the world and allow them to access the satellite via radio receiver kits. Students can receive short Morse code messages that contain inspiring or encouraging words from mentors, sponsors, and Project DaVinci team members. These messages will help get students excited about space exploration again and will shape the next generation of dreamers and explorers. 

Project DaVinci Space Ambassadors in Florida

 

Project DaVinci is also utilizing modern technologies, such as the ability to use the internet in space, to deliver the galaxy to students’ fingertips! With this connection, commonly referred to as Sat-Fi, students will be able to upload digital media to Project DaVinci’s digital time capsule that is stored on the satellite’s motherboard. This time capsule will capture the world’s favorite pictures, videos, songs, books, video games, and more. 

 

 

An image of the finished DaVinci Satellite--Courtesy of Clyde Space

 

DaVinci’s Launch:

With mentors including Burt Rutan and Julian Guthrie, Project DaVinci has surpassed many project milestones that are essential for the satellite’s upcoming launch. The team was selected by NASA in early 2016. By late 2017, the team had constructed the DaVinci Satellite in partnership with Clyde Space. The team passed the MRR (Mission Readiness Review) with NASA in December 2017 and delivered the satellite to the launch provider, Rocket Lab, in April 2018. The DaVinci Satellite is currently scheduled to launch from New Zealand in Mid December of 2018 and will begin its mission shortly after it reaches orbit.

Team photo with mentors Burt Rutan, Brent Regan, Ross Welburn, Laszlo Antal, and Blake Alfson. 

 

Funding a Satellite:

For the past 2.5 years, students on the Project DaVinci team have worked tirelessly to ensure this satellite was constructed and delivered to NASA. Project DaVinci was awarded a million-dollar launch ticket in partnership with NASA. The team has raised a whopping $200,000 in private contributions to cover the costs of the satellite and has worked with many mentors to ensure the satellite is mission-ready. However, the team is falling short on funding to complete its mission to inspire young students around the world.

 

Before the DaVinci Satellite launches in late 2018, the team needs to raise $10,000 to construct a ground station here in North Idaho. This is the ground station that will be used to upload messages that will be received by thousands of students across the globe.

 

$5,000 must be raised to cover licensing costs. The DaVinci Satellite required both an FCC license and a NOAA license to be cleared for a launch date. Both licenses required time and financial resources to secure and were a major expense for the team.

 

An additional $10,000 must be secured to pay for initial setup support from the engineering staff at Clyde Space. The DaVinci Satellite contains many new and innovative features that require experts in the field to operate once the satellite is in orbit.

 

Just $25,000 sits between the DaVinci Satellite and thousands of students around the world waiting to receive messages from space.

 

Here’s how you can help:

  1. Donate: By pledging your hard-earned money to this campaign, you will ensure that students are inspired to pursue STEM careers and join the next generation of dreamers and doers. Project DaVinci is a 501(c)(3) organization, meaning your donations are tax deductible, and if you are a citizen of Idaho, they also act as a tax credit. Sweet prizes, including limited-edition mission patches and scaled 3D models of the DaVinci Satellite, are just some of the many ways the team will thank you for your support!
  2. Share: Sharing is caring! Whether you can or cannot donate to this campaign, it costs nothing but a few seconds of your time to share this campaign with your friends and family. You can easily share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to promote Project DaVinci’s mission.
  3. Join: Registering with Project DaVinci’s website is easier than ever before! Just visit our registration page HERE, fill in the basic information, and you can officially be part of Project DaVinci’s mission to light up minds around the world with personalized messages from space.

From all of us at Project DaVinci, thank you for your continued support!

 

 

Project DaVinci

"Lighting Up Minds Around the World"

story:
What am I doing?

Hello there! My name is Breanna Berzins (if you don’t know me and you are looking at this, then THANK YOU so much for taking the time to read and hopefully partner alongside of me). I am a sophomore at a private Liberal Arts school called DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana. I have recently declared my major in Kinesiology (the scientific study of human movement), and am in the process of declaring a minor in Psychology. I was born in Arizona and have lived there my whole life up until coming to Indiana for school last fall (it’s been a rough weather adjustment). I decided to move to the Midwest because I realized that the 4 years I spend getting my undergraduate degree should be the years that I take advantage of the place I live, especially if Arizona is a place I decide to live in again once I graduate. I wanted to be able to experience living in a place I wasn’t familiar with and put myself out there to the rest of the world that is outside of Arizona. Moving to Indiana was definitely a culture (and weather) shock – but it was one of the best decisions I have ever made.

Now that I have broadened my horizons in the U.S., I have been given an opportunity to expand beyond that and broaden my horizons even more by moving to another country – another hemisphere to be exact. I am starting this campaign for one main reason: to help raise support for a study abroad trip to Australia or New Zealand. DePauw offers an opportunity for students to pursue their educational goals internationally by studying abroad. These off campus programs allow DePauw students the chance to enhance their semester academic experiences through engaging in independent study, service, and personal development opportunities. I have found a few programs held in Australia and New Zealand that would allow me to continue on with my Kinesiology and psychology studies to help with the remaining credits I need. It has been my dream for years just to travel to the Southern Hemisphere, I can't imagine actually being able to live there for 5 months.

If only money grew on trees...

I wish I had a surplus of money that I could spend on this trip, but unfortunately, I do not. My piggy bank is pretty small and has already been broken for DePauw tuition. In the end, I need to raise at least $2,000. This money will go directly to the study abroad program fee, room and board, the plane ticket there and back, and tuition.

Here is a more detailed breakdown (varies amongst the different programs):

Program Fee: $2,500

Room: $3,540 - $4,810

Board: $1,260 - $1,800

Airfare: $1,575 - $1,800

Tuition: ~ $7,500

Adding all of that together, the cost is approximately $18,000 which is about $16,000 more than my desired goal. Again, in the end, I need to raise at least $2,000. (I have even included some incentives on the side of the page to help get you even more excited about donating!) Some of the remaining costs of the program I hope to get paid for by scholarships. But, I know my parents and even myself will be the major contributors for the remaining costs. For my own personal contribution, I am saving my money by working 10 hours a week at my school and also working over the summer at Paradise Bakery when I am back home. This is SO important to me and I know I will never get a chance to do something as remarkable as this ever again in my lifetime. I realize that I, too, will have to make sacrifices to make this happen and I am 100% dedicated to putting every penny I have earned towards this opportunity. My goal for the rest of this school year and for part of the summer that I will be home (I would leave for AU or NZ at the end of June) is to save as much money as possible to make this trip a reality.

The impact you can make

I know that $2,000 is not a small amount of money, and that is why I need your help. Your contributions will help make my dreams of beginning to travel the world a reality. I want to meet people that will change my life forever and have the opportunity to be immersed in new cultures. I am thrilled to experience new things and be given opportunities to love other people well.

Don't have the money?

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. Help me get the word out! Tell your friends, family, co-workers, or even people walking down the street! Please share this campaign via Facebook, email, Twitter, Instagram, etc. to help make some noise about my story! (Use the Indiegogo share tools underneath the video)

And that’s all there is to it!

story:
Has anyone seen this poster? Of course! The picture in this flyer could very well be someone you know and love... You see them everywhere. In street corners, milk cartons, bulletin boards, etc.  It’s a known fact that our loved ones, especially children, go MISSING all the time.  For whatever reason, THEY NEED TO BE FOUND!

 

 

DID YOU KNOW?

As of December 31, 2011, the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) contained 85,158 active missing person records. Juveniles under the age of 18 account for 37,371 (43.9%) of the records and 9,832 (11.5%) were for adults between the ages of 18 and 20. ["National Crime Information Center". The Federal Bureau of Investigations. U.S. Federal Government, U.S. Department of Justice. Retrieved 19 December 2012.] HT - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber_alert


During 2011, 678,860 missing person records were entered into NCIC, a decrease of 2.0% from the 692,944 records entered in 2010. Missing person records cleared or canceled during the same period totaled 679,511. Reasons for these removals include a law enforcement agency located the subject, the individual returned home, or the record had to be removed by
the entering agency due to a determination that it is invalid.["NCIC Missing Person and Unidentified Person Statistics for 2007". National Crime Information Center’s (NCIC) Missing Person File (Federal Bureau of Investigations). U.S. Federal Government, U.S. Department of Justice. Retrieved 19 December 2012.]
HT - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber_alert


THERE IS HELP…

The AMBER Alert™ Program is a voluntary partnership between law-enforcement agencies, broadcasters, transportation agencies, and the wireless industry, to activate an urgent bulletin in the most serious child-abduction cases. The goal of an AMBER Alert is to instantly galvanize the entire community to assist in the search for and the safe recovery of the child.  [HT - http://www.amberalert.gov/]

 

HOWEVER

To avoid both false alarms and having alerts ignored as a "wolf cry", the criteria for issuing an alert are rather strict.

The U.S. Department of Justice issues the following "guidance", which most states are said to "adhere closely to" (in the U.S.):[13]

     Law enforcement must confirm that an abduction has taken place.
    The child must be at risk of serious injury or death.
    There must be sufficient descriptive information of child, captor,
        or captor's vehicle to issue an alert.
    The child must be 17 years old or younger.

Many law enforcement agencies have not used #2 as a criterion, resulting in many parental abductions triggering an Amber Alert, where the child is not known or assumed to be at risk of serious injury or death.

According to the U.S. Department of Justice, of the children abducted by strangers and murdered, 75% are killed within the first three hours. Amber Alerts are designed to inform the general public quickly when a child has been kidnapped and is in danger so that "the public [would be] additional eyes and ears of law enforcement".[11] As of August 2002, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children reported that 17 children had been successfully recovered after an Amber alert was issued, including one case in which the abductor released the child after hearing the alert.

A Scripps Howard study of the 233 AMBER Alerts issued in the United States in 2004 found that most issued alerts did not meet the Department of Justice's criteria. Fully 50% (117 alerts) were categorized by the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children as being "family abductions", very often a parent involved in a custody dispute. There were 48 alerts for children who had not been abducted at all, but were lost, ran away, involved in family misunderstandings (for example, two instances where the child was with grandparents), or as the result of hoaxes. Another 23 alerts were issued in cases where police did not know the name of the allegedly abducted child, often as the result of misunderstandings by witnesses who reported an abduction.

Seventy of the 233 AMBER Alerts issued in 2004 (30%) were actually children taken by strangers or who were unlawfully traveling with adults other than their legal guardians.
HT - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber_alert

 

Controversies

Some outside scholars examining the system in depth disagree with the "official" results. [43][44][45] A team led by University of Nevada criminologist Timothy Griffin looked at hundreds of abduction cases between 2003 and 2006 and found that Amber Alerts actually played little apparent role in the eventual return of abducted children. Furthermore, AMBER Alerts tended to be "successful" in relatively mundane abductions, such as when the child was taken by a noncustodial parent or other family member. There was little evidence that Amber Alerts routinely "saved lives", although a crucial research constraint was the impossibility of knowing with certainty what "would have" happened if no Alert was issued in a particular case.

Advocates for missing children are concerned that the public is becoming desensitized to AMBER Alerts because of a large number of false alarms
HT - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber_alert

 

WE NEED TO ACTIVELY GET INVOLVED!

 

  • Orbital Laboratories, Inc. is a small start up company that is in the process of designing a new beacon system and network. It is a new wireless system that will allow people to find things that are important to them - wallets, pets, cars, strong boxes with important insurance information, and the most precious thing of all, CHILDREN. This is NOT like other Bluetooth devices you may have seen. We currently own 2 patents on our system with one pending.




  • With this funding, in addition to the initial support we've already received from friends and families of Orbital, we will realize a new system of finding items, especially children. Our plan is to work with the Amber Alert system. We are currently in collaboration with another patent holder whose technology will eventually reduce the size of the beacon to a piece of jewelry, or to put it into the tag of clothing, or anything that your child always wears or carries with them. Our beacons are able to be labeled and re-labeled easily.

  • This unique system utilizes a powered cell phone case with initial support for the I-phone 3-5 models. Our plans is to complete the case and beacons by the end of August for beta testing, and show the system at the CES in 2014, with a limited release for the holidays.

  • This may sound like other "locator" projects that are out there but ours is covered by multiple patents, and with a range of up to one mile. You can also pair the system to other phones to create an electronic search party.

What We Need & What You Get

  • This funding will allow us to finish the phone case design with 6 models, as well as create what we call beacon DNA - beacons that can be attached to anything but also have an I/O port for other products to plug into.

  • For assisting us in this campaign, all contributors will get a perk on rollout. The fact is, we need these across the USA to test and refine the electronic ability of the system. There will be other perks in this program, including a game that will be free to all initial members. This game, which will be a free download, is based on the beacons.

  • All of the funds received will be used. We are also seeking private donations and are working on larger commitments. For instance, we have a company that is ready to move our products nationwide, and will be allowing us to use their booth at CES in 2014. So distribution is not a problem.

The Impact

This is the first time we are using this avenue for funding. With that being said, there are other projects that we have taken on and completed. This includes a new design of Television for use in Afghanistan by our troops. We completed and shipped 1,200 special televisions to our troops at Bagram Air Base in January of 2012. We have spent the rest of our time gathering the technology necessary and getting our Patents in order.

We have other products that are going to market this year including new Televisions under the name Orbital that will be available on Amazon next month.

It is never easy building something that does not yet exist. However, our team of engineers as well as our manufacturing partners are also picking up the upfront manufacturing costs to get us into production. Everyone is contributing where they can. The bottom line is, this money will allow us to help complete the work, and enable to people to track and recover children. This is why we will continue to lower the costs as permitted by the new technologies that are at our disposal.

Other Ways You Can Help

Finally, we are looking for exposure for our product lines and ideas. We need everyone’s support to get the word out on what we are about, and what we will achieve in the near future. Please help us on facebook and other social network places to get the word out! And also, please don’t forget to use your share tools available here on this site as well.  Thank you!.

THERE IS HELP…
The AMBER Alert™ Program is a voluntary partnership between law-enforcement agencies, broadcasters, transportation agencies, and the wireless industry, to activate an urgent bulletin in the most serious child-abduction cases. The goal of an AMBER Alert is to instantly galvanize the entire community to assist in the search for and the safe recovery of the child.  [HT - http://www.amberalert.gov/]
 
HOWEVER
To avoid both false alarms and having alerts ignored as a "wolf cry", the criteria for issuing an alert are rather strict. 
The U.S. Department of Justice issues the following "guidance", which most states are said to "adhere closely to" (in the U.S.):[13] 
     Law enforcement must confirm that an abduction has taken place.    The child must be at risk of serious injury or death.    There must be sufficient descriptive information of child, captor,         or captor's vehicle to issue an alert.    The child must be 17 years old or younger.
Many law enforcement agencies have not used #2 as a criterion, resulting in many parental abductions triggering an Amber Alert, where the child is not known or assumed to be at risk of serious injury or death.
According to the U.S. Department of Justice, of the children abducted by strangers and murdered, 75% are killed within the first three hours. Amber Alerts are designed to inform the general public quickly when a child has been kidnapped and is in danger so that "the public [would be] additional eyes and ears of law enforcement".[11] As of August 2002, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children reported that 17 children had been successfully recovered after an Amber alert was issued, including one case in which the abductor released the child after hearing the alert.
A Scripps Howard study of the 233 AMBER Alerts issued in the United States in 2004 found that most issued alerts did not meet the Department of Justice's criteria. Fully 50% (117 alerts) were categorized by the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children as being "family abductions", very often a parent involved in a custody dispute. There were 48 alerts for children who had not been abducted at all, but were lost, ran away, involved in family misunderstandings (for example, two instances where the child was with grandparents), or as the result of hoaxes. Another 23 alerts were issued in cases where police did not know the name of the allegedly abducted child, often as the result of misunderstandings by witnesses who reported an abduction.
Seventy of the 233 AMBER Alerts issued in 2004 (30%) were actually children taken by strangers or who were unlawfully traveling with adults other than their legal guardians.HT - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber_alert
 
Controversies
Some outside scholars examining the system in depth disagree with the "official" results. [43][44][45] A team led by University of Nevada criminologist Timothy Griffin looked at hundreds of abduction cases between 2003 and 2006 and found that Amber Alerts actually played little apparent role in the eventual return of abducted children. Furthermore, AMBER Alerts tended to be "successful" in relatively mundane abductions, such as when the child was taken by a noncustodial parent or other family member. There was little evidence that Amber Alerts routinely "saved lives", although a crucial research constraint was the impossibility of knowing with certainty what "would have" happened if no Alert was issued in a particular case.
Advocates for missing children are concerned that the public is becoming desensitized to AMBER Alerts because of a large number of false alarmsHT - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amber_alert
 
WE NEED TO ACTIVELY GET INVOLVED!
 


Orbital Laboratories, Inc. is a small start up company that is in the process of designing a new beacon system and network. It is a new wireless system that will allow people to find things that are important to them - wallets, pets, cars, strong boxes with important insurance information, and the most precious thing of all, CHILDREN. This is NOT like other Bluetooth devices you may have seen. We currently own 2 patents on our system with one pending.

With this funding, in addition to the initial support we've already received from friends and families of Orbital, we will realize a new system of finding items, especially children. Our plan is to work with the Amber Alert system. We are currently in collaboration with another patent holder whose technology will eventually reduce the size of the beacon to a piece of jewelry, or to put it into the tag of clothing, or anything that your child always wears or carries with them. Our beacons are able to be labeled and re-labeled easily.

This unique system utilizes a powered cell phone case with initial support for the I-phone 3-5 models. Our plans is to complete the case and beacons by the end of August for beta testing, and show the system at the CES in 2014, with a limited release for the holidays.

This may sound like other "locator" projects that are out there but ours is covered by multiple patents, and with a range of up to one mile. You can also pair the system to other phones to create an electronic search party.


What We Need & What You Get

This funding will allow us to finish the phone case design with 6 models, as well as create what we call beacon DNA - beacons that can be attached to anything but also have an I/O port for other products to plug into.

For assisting us in this campaign, all contributors will get a perk on rollout. The fact is, we need these across the USA to test and refine the electronic ability of the system. There will be other perks in this program, including a game that will be free to all initial members. This game, which will be a free download, is based on the beacons.

All of the funds received will be used. We are also seeking private donations and are working on larger commitments. For instance, we have a company that is ready to move our products nationwide, and will be allowing us to use their booth at CES in 2014. So distribution is not a problem.


The Impact
This is the first time we are using this avenue for funding. With that being said, there are other projects that we have taken on and completed. This includes a new design of Television for use in Afghanistan by our troops. We completed and shipped 1,200 special televisions to our troops at Bagram Air Base in January of 2012. We have spent the rest of our time gathering the technology necessary and getting our Patents in order.
We have other products that are going to market this year including new Televisions under the name Orbital that will be available on Amazon next month.
It is never easy building something that does not yet exist. However, our team of engineers as well as our manufacturing partners are also picking up the upfront manufacturing costs to get us into production. Everyone is contributing where they can. The bottom line is, this money will allow us to help complete the work, and enable to people to track and recover children. This is why we will continue to lower the costs as permitted by the new technologies that are at our disposal.
Other Ways You Can Help
Finally, we are looking for exposure for our product lines and ideas. We need everyone’s support to get the word out on what we are about, and what we will achieve in the near future. Please help us on facebook and other social network places to get the word out! And also, please don’t forget to use your share tools available here on this site as well.  Thank you!.

story:
PLEASE SUPPORT 1 YEAR OF CATALOGING & DIGITIZING THE COLLECTION

The National Library of Mongolia is home to possibly the largest single collection of Tibetan Buddhist books anywhere in the world.  No one knows for sure because the collection, which consists of books printed throughout the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries - is currently sitting uncatalogued and relatively unknown to the world. 

The Asian Classics Input Project (ACIP) has been working in Mongolia since 1999 to organise, catalogue and digitally preserve this special collection, which has only recently been unearthed and come to the attention of scholars since the end of the Soviet era. 

As the works are cataloged and digitized they are then made available to scholars around the world free of charge.  This allows the texts to be translated and shared with teachers and students who are studying the dharma.

For two years the work was put on hold due to shortfalls in funding after the financial crisis.  Project costs have increased substantially due to rising inflation and minimum wages for input operators and staff at the Library. 

ACIP and a small but devoted team of supporters have recently restarted this important project and are currently paying salaries for six employees. 

The total estimated project costs to catalogue and digitize the entire collection, estimated to be approximately 800,000 to 1,000,000 titles, is US$1.1m over the time span of about 3 years. 

In this initial fundraising effort, we aim to raise funds to support the first full year of salaries for input operators which are $500 per month for six staff, across twelve months.

This is an important step toward achieving the larger goal of cataloging the entire collection, thereby preserving one of Mongolia's important treasures of cultural heritage and a treasure of humanity for all to share.

Your support in this campaign will help in providing the world access to this important wisdom for the benefit of everyone.

If you are new to Tibetan Buddhist teachings there are very good resources we can share with you for translations and modern commentaries on how to practice, so that your life and the lives of others around you will become happier and more fulfilling.


Please join us in this historic effort!  Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Greetings,

My name is Voltaire Davis and I'm an American social entrepreneur from Los Angeles, California, who has co-developed a concept for a mobile app that can measure peoples WILLPOWER toward their goals or dream in life. I'm confident that when my app is developed it can have a significant impact on global sustainability by helping people pursue their endeavors. Due to the potential of my concept, the highly selective Amsterdam School of Creative Leadership (THNK.org) granted me admission and a partial scholarship. However, I must pay for the balance of my tuition in order to develop the app into a prototype during the next 18 months.

So here I stand, in Amsterdam, with zero dollars, two suitcases and a BIG IDEA. Challenged with the fact that I’m not allowed to work more than 10 hours per week in the Netherlands as a foreign citizen, what to do?

I'm so confident in this venture that I'm willing to make a personal sacrifice and run 1,864 miles to prove it! On September 26, 2013, in honor of my mother’s legacy, I've committed to run from Tangier, Morocco, to Amsterdam, Netherlands, to raise money for my classmates social ventures and my business. My challenge right now is that I have less than $200 in my bank account. If I'm going to be successful, I need your support and funds to continue my education and money for proper food to eat to prepare for my BIG RUN. To learn more about my story visit the following link read my BLOG "American Gypsy in Amsterdam."

Other Ways You Can Help

People who can’t contribute financially still can help in other ways... here is how: 

  1. Like the Fan Page on Facebook
  2. Follow Us on Twitter
  3. Share My Story and tell your friends why you think they should support me.
  4. Connect me to philanthropic organizations or individuals who support young social entrepreneurs and "positive" people with extraordinary ideas.
  5. Refer companies or brands that would like to sponsor the run.

story:
Short Summary

     Hello everyone! My name is Dustin Eells and I am a graduating senior at SUNY Plattsburgh in the Expeditionary Studies department. One of the final steps to graduating is planning and executing a "senior expedition". Two of my classmates, Joseph McGrath and William Nelson, have asked me to join them on their senior expedition to Yosemite Valley for 3 weeks of climbing which will include "The Nose" on El Cap, considered by many to be the most famous climb in the world.

      Aside from this expedition being a requirement for graduation, it is also a huge personal accomplishment for us 3. It will test how far we have come in this program and help take our climbing careers to the next level.

     This expedition will also help me tremendously in my path to becoming a professional outdoor guide. Future employers will recognize this accomplishment, giving me an edge in this field.

    This is a exciting time for all three of us and I truly appreciate any contributions made.

What We Need & What You Get

      The funding for this expedition will cover travel, food, camping, and equipment. Climbing equipment can be very expensive so funding is a very big factor in the success of this trip.

      To show my appreciation of your donations I will be putting together a video of our expedition so those of you who contributed can more closely witness what you helped us accomplish.

story:
Hey there! I'm currently working on my prerequisites in order to apply for the nursing program at Portland Community College, as well as raising twin toddlers. I am feeling incredibly motivated to complete doula training at Birthingway College of midwifery. I'd like to facilitate a source of income while continuing my schooling as well as get my foot in the door to the medical industry. I feel that experience with assisting women in childbirth will be enriching emotionally as well as greatly increase the likelihood of being accepted to the Nursing program. 

The only thing holding me back at this point is $1060.00.

Asking for help has historically been very difficult for me. Coming from a place of preemptive gratitude rather than guilt or embarrassment feels amazing! 

I'm excited and motivated and I can't wait to see this goal reached!

Thank you so much for your contribution. Every dollar gets me closer to my goal!


<3

Brandy

story:
Edem Dzidzienyo is a kind-hearted, serious, and intelligent man devoted to improving the community and rural development for his people. 

He is a very respectful, respectable, and honorable man.  He simply wants to help the world be a better place.  His own community struggles a lot to survive, and he wants to change that. 

He has been admitted to the University of Reading in the UK, which was no small feat in itself, but he will need help paying for tuition. 

He currently runs a small charity called Hamlet of Hope, and you can learn a bit about it at www.hamletofhope.org.  Ultimately, he needs 20,000 pounds.  At this time, in order for him to get started, he needs $5000.00.  Please consider helping Edem so that he may be enabled with a strong education that can guide him as he strives to empower his community. Truly, we are all one people, and your help can make a huge difference that could even be boundless!  Thank you for your kindness and consideration.

Then who the heck is Ivi?

 I am a friend of Edem.  He was very kind to me and helped me in my research in the past as I stayed in Ghana.  Without any sort of compensation expected, he accommodated me as I stayed at his home.  He ensured that I had food, a comfortable bed, and water to bathe.  He also helped me as we utlized taxis and tro tros around significant areas of Accra, Ghana's capital.  He is a dear brother to me.

What

He hopes to study Social Development and Sustainable Livelihoods so that he can then develop more sustainable opportunities for his community.

When

The deadline for the tuition is the end of this month (at the latest.)  If he is able to successfully collect funds, he will begin this September.
